news.title: Glasses Malone Drops Wild Megan Thee Stallion Parallel to Nicki Minaj‚Äôs Appearance at Erika Kirk‚Äôs Turning Point USA Event
news.text: Klay Thompson's girlfriend Megan Thee Stallion has been vocal about her support for Kamala Harris during her run for the presidency in 2024. In one of Harris' sorties during the campaign, Stallion performed the song "Body" while expressing her support for the then-Vice President of the U.S.A.According to rapper Glasses Malone, there are parallels to what Stallion did during Harris' 2024 campaign to pop star Nicki Minaj's appearance at Erika Kirk‚Äôs Turning Point USA Event earlier this month. For Malone, Minaj's talk with Kirk was not worse than when Stallion twerked during Harris' campaign. "No. Because Megan is a twerker," Malone said. "If Nikki would have got up there and bust a rap, we could have just talked s**t and it would have been the end of it. Bust a rap. Just get up there and rap."He clarified later on that he did not want to put anyone in a box, the same way "white folks" did to NBA superstar LeBron James, when he was speaking up on social issues. "I don't want to do her like, you know, I'm not like the white folks saying to LeBron James like, you know, shut up and dribble," Malone said. "I'm saying don't try to fly a rocket, (like) talk about the s**t you know," he added. Currently, Stallion has been in the news for her relationship with Dallas Mavericks guard Thompson. Megan Thee Stallion shows love for Klay Thompson through cookingMegan Thee Stallion has been focusing on her relationship with Klay Thompson in the past months. During Thanksgiving, Stallion said she cooked for the Thompson family to prove her love to the Mavericks player during one of her Instagram videos. ‚ÄúI was really nervous because I was like, ‚ÄòDang, I‚Äôm really finna cook for my man and his whole family,'‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI hope they love this because to show them that I really love their son.‚ÄùIn a separate interview with ESPN, Stallion gave a glimpse of what happened in the kitchen. ‚ÄúMs. Julie was the star of the show. Ms. Julie was the hostess with the mostest,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMr. Thompson said I could own my own restaurant. I am glad that I got the stamp of approval from the father. But Ms. Julie was my number one stamp of approval.‚ÄùStallion has been Stallion has been seen supporting Thompson during games as the Mavericks look to climb up the Western Conference standings in the upcoming weeks.
news.summary: Klay Thompson's girlfriend Megan Thee Stallion has been vocal about her support for Kamala Harris during her run for the presidency in 2024.
news.author: Rob Andrew Lo

news.title: Kennedy Center Head Richard Grenell Draws Spotlight After Trump Name Backlash
news.text:
Richard Grenell has suddenly become a name people are searching as controversy swirls around the Kennedy Center‚Äôs leadership and its expanding political storm. Grenell, a long-time Republican and close Trump ally, was appointed president of the Kennedy Center earlier this year after President Donald Trump reshaped the board.

The latest dispute began after the center‚Äôs board ‚Äî appointed under Trump‚Äôs chairmanship ‚Äî voted to add Trump‚Äôs name to the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Within days, jazz musician Chuck Redd canceled his annual Christmas Eve concert, explicitly citing the name change as his reason for withdrawing. Redd told The Associated Press, via WDTV, that when he ‚Äúsaw the name change on the Kennedy Center website and then hours later on the building, I chose to cancel our concert.‚Äù

Jazz musician Chuck Redd hosted the Kennedy Center annual Christmas Eve jazz event for 20 years.
He cancelled this year after the Kennedy Center board at Trump‚Äôs urging renamed the center the Trump-Kennedy Center.
Hats off to Mr. Redd!
Trump and his appointees violated the‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/zArgfgyyhm
‚Äî Feisty is proud to be a Democrat! (@FeistyLibLady) December 26, 2025

That cancellation hit a cultural nerve. According to WSLS, Grenell fired back in a strongly worded letter to Redd, calling the decision ‚Äúclassic intolerance‚Äù and saying it was costly for the nonprofit arts institution. He added that the center would seek $1 million in damages ‚Äúfor this political stunt.‚Äù

The clash over the music event is now entwined with broader legal and political fights. Democratic Representative Joyce Beatty of Ohio has filed a lawsuit to challenge the name change, arguing that altering the Kennedy Center‚Äôs name without Congressional approval might violate federal law. She also claims she was muted during the virtual board vote and prevented from speaking.

The left is boycotting the Arts because Trump is supporting the Arts.
But we will not let them cancel shows without consequences.
The Arts are for everyone ‚Äì and the Left is mad about it. https://t.co/zej4PnBNtz
‚Äî Richard Grenell (@RichardGrenell) December 27, 2025

And to top all the controversy surrounding the center, the broadcast of the Kennedy Center Honors hit a historical low this year. ‚ÄúThe Kennedy Center Honors on CBS drew its smallest audience ever on the night of December 23, 2025, averaging an estimated 2.65 million viewers,‚Äù Programming Insider data revealed. If Trump thought that his stint as the host for the annual event would draw the numbers, he was sadly wrong.

Grenell‚Äôs rise to the top of the Kennedy Center was part of a sweeping overhaul initiated by Trump earlier in 2025. Before this role, Grenell served as the United States ambassador to Germany and as acting director of national intelligence, both under Trump‚Äôs previous administration. He also worked in foreign policy and media before returning to public service.

Critics say Grenell‚Äôs leadership style and political ties have injected partisan tensions into what was traditionally a bipartisan cultural institution. Since the renaming and leadership changes, several artists and performers have distanced themselves from the Kennedy Center, citing discomfort over the institution‚Äôs direction after the Trump name was added, per People.

üö®NEW: Congresswoman Joyce Beatty (D-OH) has filed a lawsuit to stop the Trump Administration from renaming the Kennedy Center, claiming that only Congress has the legal authority to do so.
RETWEET to thank @RepBeatty for standing up to Donald Trump! pic.twitter.com/3Spl8R1Ypq
‚Äî Protect Kamala Harris ‚úä (@DisavowTrump20) December 23, 2025

For many arts fans and observers, the Redd cancellation wasn‚Äôt isolated. Even earlier this year, musicians and performers expressed frustration with Grenell‚Äôs management, including an exchange of emails about diversity and programming decisions that went viral.9

Supporters of Grenell argue he is defending the center‚Äôs financial health and broad audience reach. But opponents see the latest legal and cultural fights as emblematic of how deeply politics has seeped into an institution once seen as a national cultural bridge.

As debate over the Kennedy Center‚Äôs name and mission continues to escalate, Grenell‚Äôs role ‚Äî and his ties to Trump ‚Äî remain central to the controversy, keeping his name trending in both the cultural and political spotlight.
news.summary: A cultural fight puts the Kennedy Center‚Äôs leader in the headlines again
news.author: Tracey Ashlee

news.title: Can We Stop Pretending Kwanzaa Is a Real Holiday?
news.text:
Karenga didn't hide what he was doing, either. He openly described Kwanzaa as a cultural and political project meant to give African Americans an explicitly ideological alternative to Christmas. Everything about it ‚Äî the timing, the symbolism, the rituals ‚Äî was deliberately constructed to serve that purpose. There's nothing ancient or traditional about it. It's less than 60 years old.

But tell that to the NFL.

On Friday, my social media feeds filled up with "Happy Kwanzaa" posts from professional football teams. MLB and NBA teams joined the parade, too. All of them rushing to celebrate a holiday that most black Americans don‚Äôt actually observe. But because Kwanzaa gets pitched as a black holiday, corporate America loves to virtue signal its support for anything related to diversity, and so it is essentially compelled to pretend the holiday is important. So the posts roll out, graphics get designed, and we‚Äôre supposed to ‚Äúooooh‚Äù and ‚Äúahhhh‚Äù and pretend this matters.

While professional sports teams were crawling all over each other with their stupid Kwanzaa messages, the real proof that posting about Kwanzaa is just shameless pandering came from none other than Kamala Harris.

Last year, when she was still vice president, she posted a Kwanzaa message from her official account. "When I was growing up, Kwanzaa was a special time of reflection with family and friends," she wrote. "Let us carry the wisdom of the seven principles with us as we work to build a brighter future. Happy Kwanzaa."

When I was growing up, Kwanzaa was a special time of reflection with family and friends. Let us carry the wisdom of the seven principles with us as we work to build a brighter future. Happy Kwanzaa. pic.twitter.com/LtMJdp4ss4‚Äî Vice President Kamala Harris Archived (@VP46Archive) December 26, 2024

This year, however, the only holiday message she shared was a Christmas post, sharing a selfie of her and her Jewish husband.

From our family to yours, merry Christmas! We hope your day is filled with good people and good food. pic.twitter.com/SPQgkyRd8S‚Äî Kamala Harris (@KamalaHarris) December 25, 2025

 It is now the day after Kwanzaa, and there is nothing on her X or Facebook accounts acknowledging the holiday she previously claimed was a tradition in her household.

Of course, that story was a steaming pile of crap, too. Kamala was born in 1964, two years before the holiday even existed. No one truly believes her family celebrated this brand-new, barely known pseudo-holiday when she was a toddler. On top of that, Kamala is of Indian and Jamaican descent, not African. Her parents divorced in 1972, when she was seven, and she was raised primarily by her Indian mother, who followed Hindu traditions. The idea that Kwanzaa played any significant role in her childhood is absurd. Kamala didn't even try to identify as black until she ran for president.

Now that she's out of public office and not running for anything, Kamala couldn't be bothered to acknowledge Kwanzaa this year. The holiday she once claimed was central to her identity? Gone. Not even a perfunctory tweet. She doesn't need to pretend anymore.

But professional sports teams? They're still at it, flooding social media with Kwanzaa greetings for a holiday almost nobody celebrates. It's performative nonsense, and everyone knows it. But seriously, enough is enough. If Kamala can‚Äôt even bother to pretend anymore, neither should anyone else.
news.author: Matt Margolis

news.title: Trump says midterms will revolve around ‚Äòpricing‚Äô ‚Äì despite claiming affordability was a Democrat ‚Äòhoax‚Äô
news.text:
President Donald Trump said that the 2026 midterm elections will revolve around ‚Äúpricing‚Äù despite repeatedly describing affordability as a ‚Äúhoax‚Äù perpetuated by Democrats.

During an interview with Politico on Friday, the Republican president expressed confidence that midterm voters ‚Äî who will decide which party controls Congress next year ‚Äî will embrace his economic agenda.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs going to be about the success of our country. It‚Äôll be about pricing,‚Äù Trump told the outlet. ‚ÄúBecause, you know, they gave us high pricing, and we‚Äôre bringing it down. Energy‚Äôs way down. Gasoline is way down.‚Äù

The president‚Äôs recent emphasis on the cost of living comes after Democrats romped to victory in a string of states earlier this year, largely by tapping into economic concerns.

Recognizing the potency of the issue, Trump went on the offensive, hitting the campaign trail in Pennsylvania earlier this month to highlight his economic agenda and assuage anxieties. However, he veered off script and repeatedly downplayed worries.

‚ÄúThey have a new word. You know, they always have a hoax. The new word is affordability,‚Äù Trump said during a December 9 speech in Mount Pocono.

Democrats have complained that ‚Äúprices are too high,‚Äù Trump added. ‚ÄúYeah, they're too high because they caused them to be too high. But now they're coming down.‚Äù

He also advocated for austerity measures, stating that American children should be content with ‚Äúone or two‚Äù pencils and ‚Äútwo or three‚Äù dolls.

A day earlier, the president appeared supremely satisfied at the state of the U.S. economy, giving it an ‚ÄúA-plus-plus-plus-plus-plus‚Äù rating in an interview with Politico.

Trump‚Äôs latest comments come on the heels of a series of economic reports showing the economy performing better than many expected.

In November, inflation fell to 2.7 percent year-over-year, the smallest increase recorded since July, according to the latest consumer price index report from the Labor Department. And data published by the government this week revealed that the economy grew at an annual rate of 4.3 percent, the fastest clip in two years.

‚ÄúYou saw the 4.3 percent?‚Äù Trump said to Politico on Friday. ‚ÄúThe Democrats were exploding. Their heads were exploding.‚Äù

‚ÄúElectricity is down. It‚Äôs way down,‚Äù Trump added. ‚ÄúYou know, when the gasoline goes down and when the oil and gas go down, the electricity comes down naturally. But it‚Äôs all coming down. It‚Äôs all coming down. It‚Äôs coming beautifully.‚Äù

Still, other indicators paint a less favorable picture of the economy. For example, between January and November, corporate bankruptcies soared to a 15-year high as companies struggled to cope with Trump‚Äôs trade wars.

And recent polls show that most Americans ‚Äî including many of Trump‚Äôs own voters ‚Äî are indeed feeling squeezed by the present economic climate.

A Politico survey conducted in November revealed that 46 percent of respondents believe the current cost of living is the worst they can remember. This figure includes 37 percent of Trump 2024 voters and 53 percent of voters who cast their ballots for former Vice President Kamala Harris.

At the same time, nearly half reported struggling to afford essentials like groceries, health care and housing, while more than a quarter said they‚Äôve skipped medical appointments in the past two years due to high costs.
news.summary: President‚Äôs comments come after a series of recent economic reports showed the economy performing better than many expected
news.author: Brendan Rascius

news.title: Too Fun to Check: Has Hunter Gone MAGA?
news.text:
Alternate headline: Second look at nepo babies?

The poster boy for dissipated scions has decided to re-insert himself into the public consciousness, apparently not yet satisfied with his presidential pardon from his padre's puppeteers. Earlier this week, Hunter Biden opened up on a podcast about a wide range of topics, including his father's performance in the White House. First, though, Hunter decided to set the record straight on the infamous laptop that Joe Biden insisted was a Russian intelligence operation, his lawyers claimed was privileged and stolen, and that Hunter now says ... never existed?

Hunter Biden told podcaster Shawn Ryan in an interview that aired Monday that former Republican Mayor Rudy Giuliani of New York City ‚Äúconcocted‚Äù the laptop that was the subject of an October 2020 New York Post report. ...‚ÄúWhat I can tell you about the laptop is that there is no laptop. That‚Äôs bullshit. What was provided out there, what the-‚Äù Biden said, with Ryan asking, ‚ÄúThere was no fucking laptop?‚Äù‚ÄúThere is an actual physical laptop that somebody had, but the guy that had, that said he had the laptop, the existence of the search for the laptop came before he was even a twinkle in Rudy Giuliani‚Äôs eye,‚Äù Biden said. ‚ÄúThere were people, talk to Lev Parnas. Lev Parnas literally went to Ukraine to get a laptop from Dmytro Firtash, to get a hard drive, Hunter Biden‚Äôs hard drive from Dmytro Firtash and Andrii Derkach, in Ukraine, in Austria, four months before John Paul Mac Isaac ever even‚Ä¶ existed. And so, what they did is they cobbled together [a] stolen, concocted, fabricated mishmash of digital information, largely, which is, you know, thousands and thousands and thousands of emails‚Ä¶ from 25 years. I mean, no laptop could have held all of that.‚Äù

Oh, I don't know ... My new Macbook Pro came with a two-terabyte drive. That's more than enough room for all of my photography and email storage needs, even the pics of my experiences with hookers, blow, and guns. Of course, I mean this theoretically, since this laptop actually belongs to the Powers That Be of Townhall. Theoretical, I say. 

Really, fellas. I only have my church photography on it. Anything else on it was planted on me by the guys at Power Line. I, uh, dropped it off at a repair shop in Minneapolis, and ... you know the rest. It could be a Fraters Libertas dirty trick, too.

Truly, though, this latest claim from Hunter might tend to dent his credibility on other matters, and that's too bad. Hunter sounded much more connected to reality when it came to assessing his father's legacy as president, at least to the extent that Joe ever was president. Hunter decided to weigh in on two of his father's biggest disasters in the same podcast with Shawn Ryan, immigration and Afghanistan. And Hunter acknowledged the reality of both:

Disgraced first son Hunter Biden turned on his father, Joe, in a wide-ranging podcast interview this week, acknowledging that the 46th president‚Äôs lax immigration policy and move to pull US forces out of Afghanistan were both catastrophic failures.‚ÄúWe need vibrant immigration,‚Äù the 55-year-old told ‚ÄúThe Shawn Ryan Show‚Äù during a five-and-a-half-hour conversation that dropped Monday.‚ÄúBut we don‚Äôt want immigrants that are coming here illegally, draining us of resources, and being prioritized above people that are actual, literal heroes, that are still recovering from 21, 20 years of endless war ‚Äî or anybody else in our society.‚Äù

Hunter did try to shift the blame to Trump, but ...

‚ÄúAnd then Donald Trump stepped in six months before the [2024] election, and told [Republicans] that he was gonna primary every single one of them that voted for that, because we‚Äôre addicted to the problem,‚Äù said the younger Biden.

Yeah, well, good luck with that explanation. The crisis began as soon as Joe took office and reversed Trump's tough policies on asylum and border security. House Democrat Henry Cuellar tried to warn the Biden team about the coming catastrophe, but Joe and Kamala Harris got exactly what they wanted out of it. They wanted to pressure Republicans into accepting a high level of illegal immigration as a new baseline with that bill in exchange for a minimal amount of enforcement, claiming that it was the only way to solve the problem. Trump exposed this flim-flam within weeks of taking office, eliminating the border flood altogether without any new legislation at all. 

Hunter didn't even attempt a blame-shift on Afghanistan:

Elsewhere in the interview, Hunter admitted to interviewer Shawn Ryan that the botched bugout from Afghanistan ‚Äúwas an obvious f‚Äîing failure.‚Äù‚ÄúI think that there was a better way to do it, and ‚Ä¶ I can blame it on his generals, I can blame it on [other] people [for] the way in which we did it, but ‚Äî and my dad always knew this also, is that the buck stops with him.‚Äù

Well ... yeah, and that's exactly what MAGA argues, too. Donald Trump actually did have a better way to do it, which would have allowed for us to hold Bagram as a way to secure Kabul and the Afghan government we had meticulously nurtured for two decades. It still might have collapsed over time anyway, but it wouldn't have created Saigon II: Taliban Bug-Out-aloo. The rout in Kabul exposed Biden as an incompetent to not just MAGA but to everyone, and Biden's approval ratings never recovered from it. 

Of course, Hunter is not going to put on a red cap and shout "USA! USA!" at the next Trump rally. But at least he's a little more connected to reality than the rest of his family. 

Editor‚Äôs Note: Every single day, here at Hot Air, we will stand up and FIGHT, FIGHT, FIGHT against the radical left and deliver the conservative reporting our readers deserve. Sometimes, however, we just point and laugh, and let the radical Left embarrass itself. This is one of those times.

news.author: Ed Morrissey

news.title: Dem strategist: Left-wing billionaires are holding back their money
news.text:
Democratic strategist Julian Epstein said Friday that his party can no longer assume it will enjoy automatic backing from wealthy liberal donors.

The Democratic National Committee‚Äôs principal fundraising committee reported roughly $12 million in cash on hand while carrying nearly $16 million in outstanding debt from a recent loan, according to filings with the Federal Election Commission. During a discussion on ‚ÄúKudlow,‚Äù guest host David Asman asked why prominent left-wing billionaires have not stepped in to help stabilize the DNC‚Äôs finances. Epstein said the silence from the donor class reflects a broader ‚Äúvote of no confidence‚Äù in the Democratic Party.

‚ÄúI think what we‚Äôre seeing with the donor class right now is a lack of confidence, a vote of no confidence in the Democrats. And I think it stems back to a couple things,‚Äù Epstein told Asman. ‚ÄúThe lie about Biden‚Äôs mental health, the incompetency of the Harris campaign, and the fact that all of the data shows that the Democratic Party is deeply out of touch on almost every single economic and social cultural issue.‚Äù

Epstein said elite donors helped pull Democrats away from the political center.

‚ÄúThe irony here, David, is that the donor class is perhaps the most leftist class of the Democratic Party. They are the ones driving the Democratic Party to be out of touch. Now they are withholding their money because they don‚Äôt like the results of sort of the far-left drift,‚Äù Epstein added. ‚ÄúSo I don‚Äôt really know where the Democrats go from here. I‚Äôve argued for a Sister Souljah moment, but I don‚Äôt think a lot of people are listening to that.‚Äù

The DNC‚Äôs debt problems are not new, as the committee entered the midterm cycle months ago at a clear financial disadvantage, weighed down by lingering debt from former Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äôs 2024 presidential campaign and weak donor enthusiasm. At the time, the Republican National Committee reported raising $10.7 million in September with roughly $86 million in cash on hand, while the DNC brought in $10.3 million and held about $12 million in reserves.

The strain partly traces back to liabilities carried over from Harris‚Äôs failed presidential bid, which spent roughly $1.5 billion in just over three months. The DNC shelled out another $1.6 million in September to settle campaign-related bills, pushing total payments linked to Harris‚Äôs effort past $20 million, according to Axios.

(Featured Image Media Credit: Screenshot/Fox Business)

Content created by The Daily Caller News Foundation is available without charge to any eligible news publisher that can provide a large audience. For licensing opportunities of our original content, please contact [email protected].
news.summary: Silence from the donor class reflects a broader 'vote of no confidence' in the Democratic Party
news.author: Daily Caller News Foundation

news.title: The Dilemma for the Democrats in 2026 is ‚Ä¶ the Democrats
news.text: Most know the expression: ‚ÄúWe have met the enemy, and he is us.‚Äù As much as the Democratic leadership wants to attack President Trump in the coming new year, they first must deal with a much larger problem: the mirror. To begin with, who is the ‚ÄúDemocratic leadership?‚Äù It is a question a number in the media have asked of former Vice President Kamala Harris and others without getting many good answers. Republicans will be all too happy to keep spreading the message that the ‚Äúleaders‚Äù of the Democratic Party heading into the midterms and beyond are Zohran Mamdani, the newly elected, socialist-leaning, ‚Äúfleece the rich‚Äù mayor-elect of New York City; Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.); and Rep. Jasmine Crockett (D-Texas). This trio has seemingly provided enough far-left rhetoric (anti-rule-of-law, pro-open-borders, ‚Äúdefund the police‚Äù and wreck the economy via ‚Äúuniversal income,‚Äù etc.) to ensure tens of millions of ‚Äúcommon sense‚Äù Americans will come out to vote against their policies in 2026 and 2028. Next, we have Minnesota Governor Tim Walz (D). He is the gift which keeps on giving if you are a Republican, a fan of President Trump, or in favor of not having your hard-earned federal tax money stolen. First, he became the anchor attached to the 2024 Kamala Harris campaign, helping to sink that political vessel through his own personal flights of fancy and provable ineptitude. But now Walz surfaces yet again amid a Minnesota mess of fraud. The story is reminding the public why Trump is entirely correct to push for a regulated and secure immigration system, while also fighting to ensure that immigrants don‚Äôt game the system to abuse Americans' natural generosity. Under Walz's leadership, Minnesota has become the poster child for the issues of both immigration and fraud. Billions are alleged to have been stolen or misappropriated ‚Äî shocking allegations which have naturally spurred many to look much more deeply into the finances of other blue states led by Democratic governors. Gavin Newsom's California, anyone? All of a sudden, more and more Americans are starting to wonder how many tens of billions of their taxpayer dollars have potentially been stolen in these blue-democratic cities and states. Republicans did not cause them to think that way, but rather repeated Democratic miscues in those cities and states. For a brief, shining moment, some Democrats believed they had stumbled upon an issue that would hurt Trump and the Republicans heading into 2026: ‚Äúaffordability.‚Äù Not so much anymore. On its own, the scandal in Minnesota derails that potentially winning issue, since it bothers tens of millions of hard-working American citizens who often have so little for themselves and their families. It is hardly "affordable" to have Democratic policies, enabled by Democrats' incompetence, make a mockery of their understanding and kindness toward newcomers. But now we also have the nation's GDP growing at a "blistering 4.3 percent" annual pace. Fears about inflation are subsiding, thanks to strong wage growth and Trump's own affordability policies. That is an economic victory for Trump and the Republicans, and it has to be cited in every left-of-center news outlet across the country. To one extent or the other, bread and butter issues are always top of mind for most Americans, especially the working class. And no matter which narrative the Democrats use to attack Trump, those same Americans realize that he is the first true businessman to inhabit the Oval Office in their lifetimes ‚Äî a massively successful one at that, who has built an iconic global brand. As we head into the new year and its critically important November elections, several questions arise for the Democrats as they gaze into the mirror: Who are we? Have we confused the American electorate with our split personalities? What can we honestly tout as a victory? How will we deal with the coming civil war with the far left if we pretend to be more centrist? And how many more misappropriated-money shoes are still to drop? In the meantime, Trump, Vice President JD Vance, and the Republicans are in charge. They will gladly stand aside and let the public's focus fall on all the Democratic infighting to come. Douglas MacKinnon is a former White House and Pentagon official.
news.author: Doug Mackinnon, Opinion Contributor

news.title: Newsom has strong year in California, but is he peaking too soon?
news.text: California Gov. Gavin Newsom moved himself into front-runner status for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2028, emerging from a pack of contenders to clear leading status. It was a strong year for Newsom, whose combative approach to taking on President Trump resonated with Democrats and won favorable headlines for his team. ‚ÄúThe headline on Newsom is that this year, he became the default answer of who Democrats are thinking about for 2028,‚Äù Democratic strategist Joel Payne said. ‚ÄúHe became the stand-in at a time when the party was looking for leadership and a good spokesperson." ‚ÄúNewsom has been the officeholder who has been in the best position to counter Trump,‚Äù he said. The question for Newsom and his operation going forward is whether he can keep the excitement level up and maintain front-runner status past the midterm elections, after which the presidential battle will really heat up. Despite his strong 2025, some Democrats have openly wondered if it‚Äôs possible Newsom is peaking too soon. ‚ÄúHe fits the mood of the country and the party now, but things change quickly,‚Äù one Democratic consultant said. ‚ÄúPolitics is all about timing, and it may be too soon. We‚Äôre still at least a year away from that cycle starting.‚Äù Newsom‚Äôs lead in the Real Clear Politics average of polls for the Democratic nomination is narrow. He gets 23.6 percent compared with former Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äôs 21.4 percent in an average of polls taken between Aug. 25 and Dec. 19. Newsom‚Äôs lead is wider in one recent poll. An Atlas Intel poll this month, for example, had him getting 35 percent support compared with 16 percent for Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.), who is widely seen as a strong candidate from the left. Two other recent polls included in the Real Clear Politics average, however, show him with just a percentage point lead over Harris in the case of an Echelon Insights poll, and trailing the 2024 Democratic presidential nominee by 11 points in a Big Data Poll. Whether any of those polls mean anything is also a matter of debate. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs insane to anoint anyone a front-runner or look at polls this far out,‚Äù said Democratic strategist Eddie Vale, who opined that Newsom ‚Äúhad a great year.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very open question to see if that success translates into Democratic primary voters thinking he can win the electoral college,‚Äù Vale added. A CNN poll out this past week showed Newsom leading other would-be candidates on the Democratic side. But the same poll also said two-thirds of those surveyed said they didn‚Äôt have a specific candidate in mind for 2028. That‚Äôs a reminder that while the Beltway class is heavily focused on 2028, most of the country is not. Either way, Newsom has solidified his brand over the last year as the Trump battler-in-chief. Just last week, for example, Newsom took to social platform X to hit Trump on his newly installed White House hall of presidents, where he used plaques to hit former Democratic presidents including Joe Biden and Barack Obama. ‚ÄúInflation is up. Unemployment is up. Grocery prices are up. Electricity costs are up. And Donald Trump is spending his time doing this,‚Äù Newsom wrote in his post on X. On a more substantive level, Newsom led the effort on behalf of California‚Äôs Proposition 50, the ballot measure that voters overwhelmingly approved in November to redraw the state‚Äôs congressional districts to give Democrats an edge. The effort was a direct response to a Trump-backed effort by Texas Republicans to help GOP House candidates in the Lone Star State. It was a national political fight given its implications on the 2026 battle for the House majority. If Democrats do win back control of the House, it will be a considerable curb on Trump‚Äôs power over the latter half of his term. ‚ÄúI think it was brilliant and it was needed,‚Äù Democratic strategist Adam Parkhomenko said of the Newsom-led redistricting fight in California. ‚ÄúHe showed that he‚Äôs not only talking the talk but walking the walking." ‚ÄúHe has shown Democrats how to fight like it‚Äôs 2028. Not 1998,‚Äù Parkhomenko added. ‚ÄúAnd the key is that he didn‚Äôt necessarily invent a new playbook. He took Trump‚Äôs and made it better.‚Äù A Democratic donor added that Newsom ‚Äúhelped carry the Democratic Party on his shoulders this year while most of the party was asleep.‚Äù Trump has also helped to keep Newsom in the heart of the news cycle, frequently taking aim at the Democrat while helping to burnish his brand as a fighter, Democrats say. Last month, in an interview with Fox News, Trump called Newsom a ‚Äúhorrible governor.‚Äù ‚ÄúI knew Gavin for four years,‚Äù Trump said at the time. ‚ÄúI get along great with him. But he‚Äôs gone radical left.‚Äù In the months ahead ‚Äî particularly as he eyes 2028 ‚Äî Democrats say Newsom will have to pivot from Trump-bashing to a purveyor of ideas, particularly on economic issues. ‚ÄúHe has tried a 1000-flowers-bloom approach and has done a little bit of everything and that‚Äôs OK for now, but he has to define what his path is going to be,‚Äù Payne said. ‚ÄúI imagine we will start to get a glimpse of what a post-gubernatorial Newsom sounds like in the coming months. The big question is what issue does he glom onto and make his hobby horse?‚Äù But so far, Democrats say, the nomination fight is his to lose. ‚ÄúI think the only one who could f‚Äë‚Äë‚Äë it up for Gavin Newsom is Gavin Newsom,‚Äù Parkhomenko said.
news.author: Amie Parnes

news.title: Lizzo Trashes Nicki Minaj After TPUSA Appearance: Joined Trump's 'Side' for Money & 'Privileges'
news.text:
Left-wing pop star and Kamala Harris 2024 presidential surrogate Lizzo claims rap megastar Nicki Minaj only joined President Donald Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúside‚Äù because she sees it as ‚Äúmore profitable and more beneficial,‚Äù predicting that the public will start seeing ‚Äúan influx‚Äù of celebrities who will follow suit.

Rather than look into the reasons why Minaj would support President Trump, Lizzo oversimplified the matter by chalking it up as the ‚ÄúSuper Bass‚Äù singer simply seeking ‚Äúmoney‚Äù and certain ‚Äúprivileges.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo I‚Äôm getting texts, like, about Nicki, and I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòWhat are you talking about?‚Äô I didn‚Äôt even know,‚Äù Lizzo said, adding, ‚ÄúThen I researched and saw what was going on, and I‚Äôm gonna say it like this: celebrities‚Äô opinions of other celebrities does not matter ‚Äî so my opinion of her does not matter.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut what I will tell you is you‚Äôre about to see an influx of people who see that it is more profitable and more beneficial to join that side. You‚Äôre gonna see it. It already started, and it‚Äôs going to continue,‚Äù the ‚ÄúRumors‚Äù singer continued.

Lizzo went on to say, ‚ÄúWe got three more years‚Äù of Trump being president, during which time there will be ‚Äúpeople who are going to surprise you,‚Äù suggesting that she knows there are closet conservatives in the entertainment industry who may feel emboldened to let their opinions be known in the coming years.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to hurt your feelings,‚Äù Lizzo told her fans. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to disappoint you.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd you have to know that, like, there‚Äôs money behind everything,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúThere are privileges behind every move people in these positions make, and I‚Äôm not surprised.‚Äù

Interestingly, Lizzo‚Äôs comments about Minaj convey that the ‚ÄúTruth Hurts‚Äù singer ‚Äî who endorsed Kamala Harris in the 2024 election ‚Äî holds the narrow-minded view that no one could possibly see any advantage in supporting a Republican president unless they have some financial incentive.

Moreover, some may see the pop star‚Äôs remark that ‚Äúthere‚Äôs money behind everything‚Äù as Lizzo ‚Äî who has gone to bat for Democrats ‚Äî inadvertently revealing that she might know celebrities can, in fact, be paid for political endorsements, including possibly by Democrats, which the left has denied.

But for decades, it has been widely understood that many conservatives in the entertainment industry deliberately hide or downplay their political views in public, strongly suggesting that they do not see openly supporting Republicans as beneficial to their careers, which exist in an industry dominated by the left.

Notably, Lizzo‚Äôs remarks come after Minaj took the stage at Turning Point USA‚Äôs AmericaFest last weekend, where she praised President Trump and said that being at the event was more important than any concert she has ever performed anywhere in the world, because slain conservative icon Charlie Kirk‚Äôs organization is ‚Äúa direct link between young people and God.‚Äù

But Minaj has also offered reasons as to why she supports Trump, citing the president intervening and taking the ‚Äúmass slaughter‚Äù of Christians in Nigeria by radical Islamists ‚Äúseriously‚Äù ‚Äî an issue that is close to her heart.

On Christmas, President Trump announced that he directed the United States to carry out a ‚Äúpowerful and deadly strike‚Äù against ISIS terrorists in Nigeria, whom he identified as responsible for targeting and killing innocent Christians at historically severe levels.

Alana Mastrangelo is a reporter for Breitbart News. You can follow her on Facebook and X at @ARmastrangelo, and on Instagram.
news.summary:
Lizzo claims rap megastar Nicki Minaj only joined President Donald Trump's "side" because she sees it as "more profitable and more beneficial."


The post Lizzo Trashes Nicki Minaj After TPUSA Appearance: Joined Trump’s ‘Side’ for Money & ‘Privileges’ appeared first on Breitbart.

Tony McCollister, who appeared on A&E‚Äôs short-lived series Neighbors With Benefits, was taken into custody in Warren County and charged with pandering obscenity involving a minor and engaging in sexual conduct with animals, per WLWT.
Prosecutors allege McCollister uploaded child sexual abuse material to his Google account and committed acts involving two dogs he owned.

news.title: Democrats spy rare opening in rural America
news.text:
Spanberger, the Virginia governor-elect, won in part by focusing her messaging in rural counties on tariffs and tying the economic discomfort voters were feeling to Trump and the Republican Party. She outperformed Kamala Harris in 48 of Virginia‚Äôs 52 rural localities.

National Democrats, excited by Spanberger‚Äôs success, have made their own moves: Beyond the DCCC‚Äôs eight-figure investment into rural voters and voters of color and the new farmer-focused ad campaigns, a caucus of more than 100 moderate Democratic lawmakers recently released a policy agenda that includes passing a farm bill, expanding rural broadband funding and federal funding for local food purchases.

White House spokesperson Kush Desai defended the Trump administration‚Äôs policies and said ‚Äúsupporting rural Americans has been a key focus,‚Äù which is why the administration has sought to use tariffs to open up new export markets for farmers.

The RNC isn‚Äôt fazed either.

‚ÄúRural America won‚Äôt suddenly be tricked into thinking elite Democrats stand for their beliefs and values. The DNC spending a few bucks won‚Äôt fool rural Americans into thinking Democrats have touched grass,‚Äù RNC spokesperson Delanie Bomar said.

One Big Beautiful Mess

Trump‚Äôs signature tax-and-spending law provides Democrats with another opening to contrast their pitch against Republicans.

Rural health care centers across the country have already shuttered in response to the law‚Äôs Medicaid cuts, which will disproportionately hit communities where hospitals are few and often primary employers. Low-income Americans are quickly learning they may no longer qualify for federal food aid ‚Äî even as most of the tax breaks the GOP has touted will benefit the wealthy.

Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear, who chairs the Democratic Governors Association and represents a ruby red state, recently called the law ‚Äúa slap in the face to rural America.‚Äù

And POLITICO‚Äôs November poll revealed that voters are more likely to rely on Democrats when it comes to health care policy. More than 40 percent of those surveyed said they trusted Democrats to bring down health care costs for ordinary Americans, compared with 33 percent who said they trusted the GOP.

The message for Democrats is ‚Äúwrapped up and with a nice, tidy bow on it in the Big, Beautiful Bill,‚Äù said Christopher Borick, a political science professor who runs the Muhlenberg College Institute of Public Opinion. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs cuts to your health care, it‚Äôs cuts to rural hospitals. It‚Äôs cuts to SNAP benefits, and it‚Äôs just so tidy and neat for Democrats to go there.‚Äù

The strategy seems to be working. In a heavily Republican congressional district in Tennessee, Democrat Aftyn Behn beat expectations and outperformed Harris‚Äô 2024 margins in a bid to unseat GOP Rep. Matt Van Epps this month.

Behn‚Äôs ads largely focused on affordability and the fallout from the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, which she called the ‚Äúone big BS bill.‚Äù

That tactic resonated with voters in an off-cycle election and will only gain steam: Americans‚Äô health care premiums are set to skyrocket ahead of the 2026 midterms after Republicans declined to extend Covid-era ‚Äúenhanced‚Äù subsidies of Affordable Care Act plans in their big bill.

Will history repeat itself?

Still, some political experts question how much Democrats can loosen the GOP‚Äôs hold on rural America.

The president‚Äôs first-term tariff war also hammered farmers, but their political ties to Republicans hardly wavered at the time. Democrats in 2024 used roughly the same playbook they‚Äôre seeking to capitalize on now, arguing that Trump‚Äôs proposed policies would increase the cost of living and that his tariffs would impose a new tax on the middle class ‚Äî but they failed to gain enough ground with rural voters, enabling Republicans to win a trifecta.
news.author: Marcia Brown,Rachel Shin,Samuel Benson

By JACQUELINE LINDENBERG and ASHLEIGH GRAY 
 Published:09:25 EST, 27 December 2025 |Updated:09:25 EST, 27 December 2025 

Kim Kardashian's daughter North West shared a cozy Christmas moment with her stepmom Bianca Censori. 
The 12-year-old nepo baby - who recently made her Instagram debut last week - reposted a screenshot to her Instagram stories on Friday which was originally shared by rapper Babyxsosa. 
In the snap, the preteen could be seen sitting closely next to Censori as they held a conversation with the music artist via FaceTime.

Babyxsosa - whose real name is Jasia Makayla Abrams - added both a Christmas tree and money with wings emoji over the screenshot. 
While it is not known when exactly when the video call took place, it appears to have occurred around the holiday due to the emoji. 
Censori has spent time with North as well as her siblings since tying the knot with her father Kanye West in 2022.

The Australian-born architect has also taken on stepmom duty on a number of occasions over the years. 
Back in August of this year, Censori - who is known for donning racy looks in public - notably covered up as she spent time with the rapper's children during an outing in Los Angeles at the time. 

 Kanye West enjoys lowkey date with Bianca Censori in LA while ex Kim Kardashian is with their kids 
It seems the 12-year-old has developed a bond with Censori, and has been seen tagging along with the media personality to dinners in the past as well as trips.
Back in 2023, the pair were seen joining West for a meal at the celebrity hotspot Nobu located in Malibu. 
And last year, Censori took on stepmom duties once again as both she and North grabbed food at a Popeyes as well as McDonald's during a getaway to Paris. 
North's latest repost comes just days after she made her official Instagram debut on December 19. 
Her first post was a slightly blurred image of herself as she flashed peace signs towards the camera. 
Just one week after she joined the social media platform, the preteen has already garnered nearly 1 million followers.

Her next post was a closeup snap as she placed her hands over her face while partially showing off a stylish outfit.
The big step comes after North's father Kanye West had voiced his disapproval of his eldest daughter's social media activity under the supervision of her mother. 
Back in 2022, the Heartless rapper said that he told his ex-wife that he did not want their four kids on social media and added that he was also 'not allowing my daughter to be used by TikTok.'
The bio on North's Instagram account currently reads: 'account managed by parents.' 
The nepo baby's third post to her new Instagram account was shared on Christmas Day - where she proudly showed off diamond 'shark teeth' grillz. 
She unveiled the extravagant custom-made set that were crafted by celebrity jeweler Johnny Dang. 
North child proudly flashed the diamond-encrusted pieces across multiple photos. To complement the latest accessory, the tween sported what's become her signature turquoise-colored hair.
She wore a white sweatsuit covered in black graphic print, completing the look with a pair of white, high top Chrome Hearts sneakers.

North captioned the post with a single drip of water emoji, and her post has since raked in over one million likes. 
Dang reposted the photos and described his work as '1/1 shark grillz w/ baguette,' adding, 'Welcome to #flawlessgang.' 
The upload also featured snapshots of her posing in her billionaire mother's private jet, Kim Air.
The fashionista, already known for her bold style choices, was fully glammed up in a face of makeup that included false eyelashes and lip gloss.
She also flaunted a long manicure with sharp, pointed tips and spiky 3D designs.
Erykah Badu showed love by dropping four blue heart emojis in the comments. And 18-year-old internet personality Lil Tay wrote, 'Swag overload.' 
Her new grillz and Instagram debut comes not long after the preteen has previously sparked both concern and criticism for her style. 
Earlier this month, North clapped back at critics over her finger piercing - months after she first revealed the controversial bling.

A few months later in October, the preteen took to her joint TikTok account she shares with her mom and debuted fake face tattoos as well as grillz
In August, North showed off what appeared to be a dermal piercing on her right hand during a trip to Italy with her mother - and consisted of two small silver balls below her knuckle on her middle finger.
A few months later in October, the preteen took to her joint TikTok account she shares with her mom and debuted fake face tattoos as well as grillz.
'Fake piercings and fake tatts for life,' the preteen wrote in the caption of the one of the posts.
Some social media users speculated that the look could simply be a costume for Halloween while others had differing opinions.
North could also be seen sporting sparkling blue nails as well as blue eye contacts and what appeared to be fake eyelashes. 
Kardashian soon clapped back after her eldest child was criticized by trolls over the look.

'North, if she ever posts a TikTok, it's on my phone, so she has to ask my approval, and then I post it, whatever. The comments, all that's on my phone,' Kardashian said 
The reality star responded to a TikTok video uploaded by Daily Mail Australia which covered the backlash and penned in the comment section, 'This is such a non-issue.' But it was later revealed it was North herself who penned the short message.
During an appearance on Complex's GOAT Talk YouTube series last month, the SKIMS founder labeled the harsh criticism from trolls as both 'disturbing' and 'horrible.'
'North, if she ever posts a TikTok, it's on my phone, so she has to ask my approval, and then I post it, whatever. The comments, all that's on my phone.'
The star added, 'So her and her girlfriends, they love doing costumes, they love doing looks, and so, it's Halloween season, so they put on fake tattoos on their face, fake piercings.
'They all had their colored hair. They looked like an opium Powerpuff Girls ‚Ä¶ [that's] what they were going for.'

View gallery

During an episode of the Call Her Daddy podcast in October, Kardashian reflected on her eldest daughter's bold style as well as her maturity; seen in October in Paris 
During an episode of the Call Her Daddy podcast in October, Kardashian reflected on her eldest daughter's bold style as well as her maturity.
'She's really mature in one sense where she'll be like, 'Mom, I saw this and I don't really care that they don't like... my blue hair or this or that.' She's really confident and is like, 'I probably wouldn't be hanging out with those people.''
When it comes to fashion mistakes and allowing North to wear certain looks, the star asked for a 'little bit of grace.'
'I'm like, okay, we're never wearing that again. Unfortunately, we made that mistake in front of the whole world,' Kardashian said while also adding that 'as a mom, you're kind of like learning at the same time.'

news.title: Ilhan Omar‚Äôs hubby‚Äôs $30M firm quietly scrubs names from website ‚Äì as ‚ÄòSquad‚Äô member faces mounting questions on sudden wealth amid Minnesota welfare fraud
news.text:
Embattled Rep. Ilhan Omar‚Äôs husband‚Äôs venture capital firm quietly scrubbed key officer details ‚Äî including former Obama officials ‚Äî as scrutiny grows over the family‚Äôs skyrocketing wealth, The Post has learned.

Omar (D-MN) went from nearly broke to being worth up to $30 million in just a year ‚Äî as a massive, up to $9 billion fraud scheme involving the Somali community in her district unfolded right under her nose in Minnesota.

Close to 90 people have been charged so far, including at least three with direct ties to the lefty Squad member, though she has not been charged. 

It was Somalia-born Omar ‚Äî who was seen in a resurfaced video last month dishing out food in a restaurant now at the heart of the scandal ‚Äî who introduced the legislation critics say paved the way for what the feds have called the largest fraud of the pandemic.

The Jimmy Choo wearing socialist introduced the MEALS Act in Congress in 2020, relaxing oversight of government sponsored children‚Äôs meals programs during the pandemic, which critics say allowed fraudsters to claim they served millions of meals without verification, while pocketing millions of dollars in government subsidies.

Shortly after the scheme played out, Omar‚Äôs husband, political consultant Tim Mynett, launched Rose Lake Capital in 2022, a venture capital management firm.

The company saw its reported value go from nearly zero in 2023, to between $5 million and $25 million in just a year, and somehow claims to having already amassed $60 billion assets under management ‚Äî an amount many money managers on Wall Street only dream of.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of strange things going on,‚Äù said Paul Kamenar, counsel to the National Legal and Policy Center. ‚ÄúShe was basically broke when she came into office and now she‚Äôs worth perhaps up to $30 million‚Ä¶she needs to come clean on these assets.‚Äù

Rose Lake Capital, which touts its ‚Äúdeep global networks built from on-the-ground work in more than 80 countries,‚Äù had less than $1,000 in assets in 2023, according to Omar‚Äôs financial disclosure.

Yet despite the reported windfall, the business‚Äôs only address is a WeWork in DC, according to its LinkedIn page.

Between September and October ‚Äî when federal prosecutors announced charges to eight more individuals, including six of Somali descent, for their roles in the welfare scheme ‚Äî the names and bios of Rose Lake Capitals‚Äôs nine officers and advisors were removed from the website. None of them were charged in the fraud.

These names include lobbyist and former Obama Ambassador to Bahrain Adam Ereli; former Senator and Obama Ambassador to China Max Baucus; DNC Finance Chair associate Alex Hoffman; former DNC treasurer William Derrough and former ex-CEO of Amalgamated Bank Keith Mestrich, who once described Amalgamated as ‚Äúthe institutional bank of the Democratic Party.‚Äù 

Meanwhile Mynett‚Äôs other business, a California winery that previously faced fraud allegations and was declared a failed venture in 2023, was suddenly worth between $1 million and $5 million in 2024 ‚Äî a windfall of 9,900%.

The fraud case involved a wine investor suing Mynett in Oct. 2023, accusing him of swindling him of $900,000 as he ‚Äúfraudulently misrepresented ‚Ä¶ that estCru, LLC was a legitimate company.‚Äù Mynett claimed he simply struggled to build a business during the pandemic.

The case settled out of court in November.

The winery, eStCru, at some point around 2022 promoted a line of wines with names like ‚ÄúBlockchain‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Devil‚Äôs Lie,‚Äù with a prestigious California winemaker who said she abruptly stopped getting paid in early 2023. The business was only worth between $15,000 and $50,000 in Omar‚Äôs financial disclosure that year, making the sudden windfall the next year even more puzzling.

It, too, is listed as operating out of a WeWork, and doesn‚Äôt appear to actually sell any wines anymore, according to extensive internet searches.

Despite the high worth placed on the business, its website is a broken link, the phone number is disconnected and the last social media post for the winery dates back to 2023.

When she first took office in 2019, the left-wing ‚ÄúSquad‚Äù member declared a net worth between negative $25,000 and negative $65,000, claimed to own no assets and only carrying student and car debt.

Now Omar‚Äôs assets have suddenly skyrocketed to anywhere between $6 million to $30 million, according to her latest financial disclosure ‚Äî just months after the congresswoman dismissed claims she was a millionaire as ‚Äúridiculous‚Äù and ‚Äúcategorically false.‚Äù 

Her links to the Minnesota welfare scheme have started to come to light in recent weeks.

Her campaign received $7,400 in direct donations from at least three now-convicted fraudsters, though the Squad member defended she returned the donations after the scandal broke.

She‚Äôs been closely linked to at least two individuals from Minnesota‚Äôs Somalian community who‚Äôve been charged in the fraud.

One is Salim Ahmed Said, the co-owner of Safari Restaurant, where Omar held her 2018 congressional victory party.

Said was found guilty in August of stealing more than $12 million for serving 3.9 million ‚Äúphantom‚Äù meals during the COVID-19 pandemic, blowing much of the money on a $2 million Minneapolis mansion and a $9,000-a-month shopping habit at Nordstrom, according to prosecutors.

As the scam was underway in 2020, Omar even appeared on video at Minneapolis‚Äô Safari Restaurant to praise the program.

‚ÄúEvery day Safari provides 2,300 meals to children and their families,‚Äù she boasted in Somali in the video while being filmed handing trays of food in a parking lot with her pandemic-era facemask pulled down below her nose.

The other individual, Guhaad Hashi Said, worked on Omar‚Äôs campaign in 2018 and 2020, and pleaded guilty in August to running a fake food site called Advance Youth Athletic Development, where he falsely claimed to serve 5,000 meals a day and pocketed $3.2 million out of the food program. 

On Capitol Hill last week, Omar said she had no regrets about introducing the MEALS Act. 

‚ÄúAbsolutely not, it did help feed kids,‚Äù she told a reporter.

When reached for comment, Omar‚Äôs communications director sent The Post a message saying the entire office was closed until Jan. 5 ‚Äì without offering an alternative contact.

Mynett did not return The Post‚Äôs messages, and both his businesses‚Äô numbers were not functional.

‚ÄúDoes Ilhan Omar know these people? Are they from her wonderfully managed Home Country of Somalia?‚Äù President Trump posted on his Truth Social platform in September when the news of new charges first broke.

Minnesota governor Tim Waltz ‚Äì Kamala Harris‚Äô former running mate ‚Äì has also faced intense scrutiny for letting the scandal unfold under his watch.

Education Secretary Linda McMahon wrote a letter calling for him to resign, and Rep. Tom Emmer (R-MN) hinted at possible criminal charges.

‚ÄúMinnesota, under Governor Waltz, is a hub of fraudulent money laundering activity,‚Äù Trump said last month. ‚ÄúSomali gangs are terrorizing the people of that great state, and billions of dollars are missing. Send them back to where they came from.‚Äù

The Treasury and Justice Department has already launched an investigation into the alleged money laundering.
news.summary: The Jimmy Choo wearing socialist introduced the MEALS Act to Congress in 2020, relaxing oversight of children's meals programs and paving the way for the scheme the feds said could top $9 billion.
news.author: Gabrielle Fahmy,Geoff Earle

news.title: Elon Musk Calls Tim Walz a 'Crook' and Demands Prosecution Over ¬£7bn Minnesota Fraud Scandal
news.text: Tech billionaire Elon Musk has intensified his attacks on Minnesota Governor Tim Walz, branding him a 'crook' and calling for his prosecution over a sprawling fraud scandal that federal prosecutors say could involve up to ¬£7 billion ($9 billion) in stolen taxpayer funds.The Tesla and SpaceX CEO shared a post on X calling to prosecute Walz in response to investigative content posted by YouTuber Nick Shirley, whose videos have exposed alleged fraud schemes across Minnesota's welfare and Medicaid programmes.'Tim Walz is a crook', Musk wrote on Sunday.A Minnesota Department of Human Services staff account replied: '[Walz] absolutely is hiding fraud AND has retaliated & destroyed the lives of many whistleblowers'.Federal Prosecutors Call Fraud 'Industrial-Scale''The fraud is not small. It isn't isolated. The magnitude cannot be overstated', First Assistant US Attorney Joe Thompson said during a press conference on 18 December. 'What we see in Minnesota is not a handful of bad actors committing crimes. It's a staggering, industrial-scale fraud.'Federal authorities have uncovered alleged schemes spanning 14 high-risk programmes, including housing assistance, autism therapy, and disability supports. Thompson had earlier suggested that half or more of the ¬£14 billion ($18 billion) billed since 2018 could be fraudulent.The investigations grew from the ¬£195 million ($250 million) Feeding Our Future scandal. Autism-related Medicaid claims surged from ¬£65 million ($83 million) in 2021 to ¬£267 million ($342 million) in 2024.House Republicans Join Calls for AccountabilityHouse Oversight Committee (HOC) Chairman James Comer told reporters that the 'walls are caving in' on Walz. 'The key to a good congressional investigation is having whistleblowers. And, fortunately for us, we have some state employees who have bravely stepped forward.'US House Majority Whip Tom Emmer echoed Musk's criticism on X. 'There's no way the Walz administration didn't know about the billions being stolen in fraud', the Minnesota Republican wrote. 'Whoever knew, even up to the high levels, must be held accountable.'Daycare Centre Video Sparks Viral OutrageThis week, YouTuber Nick Shirley posted footage showing a Minnesota daycare with 'Learning' misspelled on its sign that allegedly received ¬£3.1 million ($4 million) in state funds.When investigators approached the 'Quality Learing Center' in Minneapolis, a woman shouted warnings about Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Shirley presented documents showing the centre received ¬£1.5 million ($1.9 million) in fiscal year 2025 alone.Walz Denies WrongdoingGovernor Walz, for his part, questioned whether federal prosecutors' claims were politically motivated. 'You should be equally outraged about $1 or whatever that number is, but they're using that number without the proof behind it', Walz had said.A Walz spokesperson called the investigation 'a coordinated political attack to try to silence one of the President's most effective critics'.History of Animosity Between Musk and WalzThe clash escalates tensions between Musk and Walz, dating back to the 2024 presidential campaign when Walz served as Kamala Harris's running mate.During the campaign, Walz called Musk a 'dipshit' and questioned his government contracts. Walz reportedly celebrated when Tesla's stock declined, despite Minnesota's state pension fund holding 1.6 million shares in the company.The confrontation intensified after Donald Trump appointed Musk to lead the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), giving the billionaire a platform to scrutinise government waste and fraud.
news.author: Stephanie Cruz

news.title: ‚ÄòTurnout Machine‚Äô Trump to Go Full-Throttle in 2026 Midterm Blitz
news.text:
White House Chief of Staff Susie Wiles has revealed that President Donald Trump will aggressively campaign for GOP candidates during the midterms, treating the elections "like it's 2024 again."

Traditional tracks have involved limiting Trump's exposure for Republican candidates in contested elections in the hopes that he won't generate a backlash turnout for Democrats. Wiles' strategy would be a bold departure from that midterm playbook.

And it means the party will embrace a full-throttle defense of the policies and platforms that led to the President's dominating performance in 2024 when he easily dispatched Kamala Harris, whom Democrats and a compliant media heavily promoted as the second coming of Obama.

"Typically, in the midterms, it's not about who's sitting at the White House. You localize the election, and you keep the federal officials out of it," Wiles said in an appearance on "The Mom View" podcast. "We're actually going to turn that on its head and put him on the ballot."

"Because so many of those low propensity voters are Trump voters," she added, noting that some results in 2025 show "what happens when he‚Äôs not on the ballot and not active."

"He's going to campaign like it's 2024 again‚Ä¶He's a difference maker, and he's certainly a turnout machine."

READ MORE: Dems' Theory on Kamala‚Äôs Loss Goes Up in Smoke: Shocking Analysis Shows Trump Could Have Won by Even More

'We Don't Dispute' It: Georgia 315k Vote Bombshell Blows a Big Hole in 2020's 'Most Secure Election' Lie

Wiles said she hasn't quite broken the news to President Trump that he'll be touring the country on the campaign trail yet, but we doubt he'll be adamantly opposed to holding rallies and dancing to the YMCA for candidates who support him.

This will be welcome news for conservatives who remember the frustration of past midterms. In 2018, during Trump's first term, Republicans lost control of the House in a significant setback, flipping dozens of seats to Democrats despite holding the Senate.

Fast forward to 2022, when the much-hyped "red wave" never materialized. Republicans narrowly took the House but failed to deliver the sweeping victories expected under a deeply unpopular Biden administration. Turnout among the MAGA base was lackluster in several battlegrounds, allowing Democrats to overperform.

Republicans opposed to the new strategy might want to look at their own record before chiming in. President Trump has been working tirelessly since re-entering the Oval Office. The GOP-led Congress? Not so much.

That might not be the best record to run on.

A study of the 2024 presidential election revealed that, contrary to the media narrative, Harris was not a victim of low turnout. In fact, GOP turnout was strong thanks to Trump being on the ballot, and the study suggested that had he driven more voters to the polls, his already big victory would have been even larger.

David Shor, a Democrat data scientist and political consultant renowned for analyzing political polls, refuted the theory that voter turnout would have helped give Kamala the edge.

"The reality is if all registered voters had turned out, then Donald Trump would‚Äôve won the popular vote by 5 points [instead of the roughly 1.6+ points]," he explained. 

"So, I think that a 'we need to turn up the temperature and mobilize everyone' strategy would‚Äôve made things worse."

And there you have it. Republicans, as Wiles is suggesting, "need to turn up the temperature and mobilize everyone." Who better to do that than the most consequential political figure of the modern era? The man who swept the battleground states where GOP candidates in 2022 struggled.

By nationalizing the midterms and putting Trump front and center‚Äîwith rallies, endorsements, and his massive war chest‚ÄîRepublicans can drive turnout among the working-class voters who propelled him to victory last year.

Editor‚Äôs Note: Do you enjoy RedState's conservative reporting that takes on the radical left and woke media? Support our work so that we can continue to bring you the truth.
