news.author: Rusty Weiss

news.title: The fight for young men intensifies ahead of the 2026 midterm elections
news.text: Winning the hearts and minds of young men has been at the center of politics over the past year. Republicans sought to cement President Donald Trump‚Äôs gains, while Democrats, fearing they could lose an increasingly disaffected segment of the electorate for a generation, launched a series of initiatives to prevent that. Ahead of next year‚Äôs midterms, some Democrats say the momentum is shifting. High-profile Democrats running in last month‚Äôs elections ‚Äî Abigail Spanberger in Virginia, Mikie Sherrill in New Jersey and Zohran Mamdani in New York City ‚Äî improved on the party‚Äôs poor performance among young men one year before. Some 2028 Democratic presidential contenders launched policy initiatives aimed at men and boys. And in Trump‚Äôs first year in office, many young men say they feel a continued economic and social malaise, cutting into his support with that key group. ‚ÄúI never want to hear again that the Democratic Party has a problem with young men,‚Äù Democratic National Committee Chair Ken Martin told reporters after the November elections. While some Democrats are taking an early victory lap, members of both parties say the fight is far from over. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs some bed-wetting going on amongst some folks who are like, ‚ÄòWell, Trump‚Äôs numbers have slipped with all these groups that he won big with last year,‚Äô‚Äù said a senior Republican strategist, who was granted anonymity to speak candidly about the matter. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs just shortsighted. ... The Republican ecosystem is just a little bit stronger in this space.‚Äù In addition, multiple Democrats said that while they‚Äôve been encouraged by the progress the party has made, there remains a level of discomfort among some party leaders in speaking to those issues. At last month‚Äôs Symposium on Young American Men, a conference put on by The Lafayette Company, a conservative communications firm, to discuss crises facing the demographic, Sen. Ruben Gallego, D-Ariz., said some in the party still have a fear of being ‚Äúcanceled‚Äù for homing in on the subject. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs OK to reach out to men,‚Äù Gallego said. ‚ÄúTalk to men. Talk about men being men.‚Äù Republicans, meanwhile, plan to hammer Democrats ahead of the midterms as out of touch with the concerns of young men while projecting improved economic standing for them in the new year, pointing to tax provisions in Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúBig Beautiful Bill,‚Äù including some about tipped wages. The senior Republican strategist said the midterms will be decided by voters‚Äô attitudes on Trump and the economy, predicting sentiment will improve as Trump‚Äôs agenda fully sets in. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of folks who feel that they are not where they should be, they‚Äôre falling behind,‚Äù this person said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a general unsettlement. Young men are especially there when you look at job prospects, AI, there‚Äôs uncertainty in general. And you add in the fact that you can‚Äôt buy a house, you can‚Äôt find a girlfriend. ... A lot of folks look to Trump for solutions.‚Äù The fight could define several critical midterm races, with Democrats hoping to build on their 2025 gains while Republicans still work to figure out how to get inconsistent voters to turn out without the president at the top of the ticket. A senior GOP Senate aide said that ‚Äúto the extent‚Äù Republicans are pondering how to get disaffected young men back to the polls next fall, ‚Äúthey‚Äôre just hoping Trump does it‚Äù for them. While it‚Äôs difficult to measure how Trump‚Äôs standing among young men has ebbed, this month‚Äôs Yale Youth Poll found his gains with young voters last year have largely been wiped out this year. The survey found that just 34% of voters ages 18 to 22 approved of Trump, in addition to 32% of voters ages 23 to 29. Last year, Trump won 42% of those under 30, a traditionally left-wing electorate that shifted substantially rightward from 2020. Economic sentiment appeared to be the biggest factor in the shift. Mamdani, Spanberger and Sherrill all focused on affordability in their campaigns and not only improved among young men over 2024 Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris but were also able to win over 7% to 9% of Trump voters in their elections, per NBC News exit polls. Youth unemployment ‚Äî for those ages 16 to 24 ‚Äî was at 10.8% in July, rising year over year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The unemployment rate in November for U.S. residents ages 20 to 24 hit 8.3% in November, BLS data showed, down from 9.2% in September but still the highest since 2021. And this spring‚Äôs Harvard Youth Poll found that roughly 4 in 10 of those under 30 were ‚Äúbarely getting by‚Äù financially. Christian G., 25, an independent from Clifton, New Jersey, said it was continued disappointment with the economy that had him voting for Sherrill after having backed Trump. ‚ÄúI feel like I expected certain things to be improved or certain things to become more affordable, and it did the exact opposite,‚Äù he said in a recent focus group observed by NBC News and produced by Syracuse University and the research firms Engagious and Sago, adding: ‚ÄúI would say for me it is kind of a testament to how, I guess, trust was lost over the year. Whereas I voted for him back in ‚Äô24, now, a year later, I‚Äôm feeling let down. I wanted to be a little more logical in my approach and vote for someone who I thought would benefit me more.‚Äù It‚Äôs not what many Democratic leaders figured when they entered the year trying to tackle Republicans‚Äô advantage among young men ‚Äî an edge they believed was due to the ‚Äúmanosphere,‚Äù a universe of apolitical to explicitly right-wing podcasters and streamers who embraced Trump in last year‚Äôs election. Some Democrats urged party leaders to break into that space, while others were willing to spend millions to fund their own male-friendly content platform. Thinking about the project to essentially create a left-wing Joe Rogan, Virginia state Del. Josh Thomas, a Democrat who spoke at last month‚Äôs Symposium on Young American Men, laughed. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm laughing because it ain‚Äôt that hard if you‚Äôre being yourself,‚Äù he said, adding: ‚ÄúAnd so I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs a good use of donor funds to try and re-create a new ecosystem or shoehorn people into an existing ecosystem. But we have ... very earnest and sincere Democratic leaders who are men who can speak authentically about what it means to be a man at an earlier time and also what it means to be a man today.‚Äù One Democratic man who found success in such spaces was Mamdani, who won young men by roughly 40 points over former Gov. Andrew Cuomo last month. He has made a series of high-profile podcast appearances this year, including on ‚ÄúFlagrant,‚Äù a prominent comedy program Trump appeared on last year, and ‚ÄúThe Adam Friedland Show.‚Äù In an interview, Mamdani said he was struck by how many New Yorkers he engaged with came across him only through his appearances on shows like ‚ÄúFlagrant.‚Äù He said a critical lesson for Democrats ‚Äúis to stop treating young people and young men with the condescension that we often see and hear in our politics.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat I found time and time again is that affordability was not something that needed any translation in young people‚Äôs lives, that this was something that was the difference between whether or not they could move out of their parents‚Äô apartment and live on their own or not,‚Äù said Mamdani, the 34-year-old avowed democratic socialist. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs oftentimes even this attempt at trying to speak to young people, especially young men, slowly, through the prism of friends or memes, when you can, in fact, speak directly to them and to their problems.‚Äù Mamdani also connected issues around the cost of living with male loneliness and alienation. ‚ÄúPart of this story that we are telling is that the crisis of cost has also denied so many people the engagement with their own city and the sense of themselves as being someone who does more than just exist between work and home,‚Äù he said. Mamdani, whose campaign held high-profile free events, including a soccer tournament and a scavenger hunt, said he‚Äôs thinking of how to spur more free or low-cost events in the city that young people can take part in. Elsewhere, Democrats across the spectrum are coming forth with ideas to address an array of male-centric issues. Maryland Gov. Wes Moore recently announced an initiative to hire more male teachers, while California Gov. Gavin Newsom, who said Democrats had ‚Äúwalked away‚Äù from men‚Äôs and boys‚Äô issues, signed executive orders this year to address male suicide and launch a ‚ÄúCalifornia Men‚Äôs Service Challenge.‚Äù In an interview, Thomas noted that he authored legislation to create Virginia‚Äôs first governor‚Äôs advisory board on boys‚Äô and men‚Äôs issues. ‚ÄúI think men have seen ... there‚Äôs been a different focus in the Democratic Party that maybe didn‚Äôt exist in October of last year,‚Äù he said. Yet voters often feel differently about state and local elections than they do about national ones. Alex Lieberman of Brooklyn, New York, said that even though he backed Mamdani in November, he would vote for Trump for a third time if he could. (Without Trump on the ballot, Lieberman said, he would back whoever the more populist option is.) ‚ÄúI think he has fulfilled his campaign promises,‚Äù Lieberman, who is in his 20s and said he was inspired to vote for Mamdani in part because of his focus on affordability and small-business issues, said of Trump. ‚ÄúAnd I think that everything that people are not happy with, I just don‚Äôt, frankly, understand, because it was exactly what it was like in the first term.‚Äù In office, Trump hasn‚Äôt made such explicit appeals to young men, though allies have said his agenda ‚Äî particularly on the economy, diversity and immigration ‚Äî has them in mind. Sen. James Lankford, R-Okla., told NBC News at the Symposium on Young American Men that Trump has sought to bolster the standing of young men, ‚Äúbut I haven‚Äôt heard him speak specifically ... about young men much, other than celebrating excellence and achievement, celebrating hard work.‚Äù Lankford said he has heard the conversation around issues affecting young men shift over the past year, saying he no longer hears much, if any, discussion of ‚Äútoxic masculinity,‚Äù a concept that conservatives have criticized for years as part of broader left-wing excess. Similarly, the right has taken sharper aim this year at diversity initiatives, claiming they hamper the prospects of younger white men. To maintain their strength with young men, a longtime pro-Trump operative said, Republicans will capitalize on diversity policies they feel a future Democratic presidential nominee will embrace. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we‚Äôve lost them,‚Äù this person said of young men. ‚ÄúI still think our party will be the one that has a more appealing vision. Will they turn out in the midterms for random Republicans? Maybe not. Were they turning out for the midterms before? No. Really, what we‚Äôre talking about is will they be there in ‚Äô28.‚Äù
news.author: Allan Smith

news.title: Five Senate Seats Most Likely to Flip from Republicans to Democrats in 2026
news.text: Democrats are hoping to overcome a challenging map and win control of the Senate in November as polls suggest several races in states won by President Donald Trump could become competitive. In a statement to Newsweek, NRSC Regional Press Secretary Nick Puglia expressed confidence in Republicans‚Äô chances, saying that Democrats are ‚Äúthe most unpopular they‚Äôve ever been.‚Äù Why It Matters Roughly one-third of Senate seats are up for re-election in November. Democrats are optimistic about their chances of winning control of the House‚Äîbut their math in the Senate is tougher. Republicans hold 53 seats, and Democrats hold 47 seats, so they must pick up four seats to win a majority. They will have to win more conservative states to win a majority. What to Know The seats held by GOP Senator Susan Collins in Maine, a state Trump has lost in each of his three runs, and retiring Senator Thom Tillis in North Carolina, which Trump won by only about 3 points last November, are viewed as Democrats‚Äô best pickup opportunities. But no other Republicans representing single-digit Trump or states won by former Vice President Kamala Harris are up for reelection. This means Democrats must win more solidly conservative territory to win a majority. Democrats are also defending two seats in states won by Trump‚Äîthe seats in Georgia held by Senator Jon Ossoff and Michigan by retiring Senator Gary Peters. Stephen Farnsworth, political science professor at the University of Mary Washington, told Newsweek the Senate ‚Äúseems more likely to remain in Republican hands than not.‚Äù ‚ÄúDemocrats have good pickup opportunities in NC and ME‚Äîand perhaps an outside chance in Ohio. Even so, a very good election night for Democrats in the upper chamber would only bring the Senate to 50-50, with a Republican VP serving as the tie-breaker,‚Äù he said. Trump‚Äôs messaging on the economy will be a key question for Republicans. ‚ÄúVoters will not be distracted from poor economic performance. Republicans need voters to feel better about their financial situation - and soon‚Äîif they hope to retain control of the House,‚Äù he said. The Cook Political Report lists five Republican-held seats as potentially being competitive. Maine and North Carolina are viewed as toss-ups, Ohio is viewed as Leans Republican, and Iowa and Texas are both viewed as Likely Republican. Here is a look at the GOP-held seats considered the most competitive ahead of the midterms. Maine In Maine, Collins has won in tough environments before‚Äîmost recently in 2020, when she won despite former President Joe Biden carrying the state by 9 points. But 2026 may prove to be her toughest race yet. Despite the nation drifting 6 points rightward in 2024, Maine barely budged, backing Harris by 7 points. It‚Äôs not clear who she will face in the general election, as Democrats in Maine are set to decide a competitive primary between Governor Janet Mills and Graham Platner. Mills has won by large margins in her elections, so many Democrats view her as the strongest candidate to defeat Collins. But more progressive Democrats believe Platner may have a more inspiring message and represent a new generation of leadership. He has faced backlash for old social media posts, but it‚Äôs not clear how that has reshaped the campaign. The most recent poll of the race shows a close election. The Pan Atlantic Research poll of 820 likely voters from November 29-December 7, 2025, showed Collins and Mills in a tie (43 percent each), while Platner led Collins by a single point (43 percent to 42 percent). A poll from the Maine People‚Äôs Research Center gave Collins an advantage over Mills (46 percent to 42 percent), but Platner a lead over Collins in the hypothetical matchup (45 percent to 41 percent). It surveyed 783 likely voters from October 26-29, 2025, and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points. North Carolina North Carolina represents Democrats‚Äô other prime target. It gave Trump a 3-point victory last November and remains one of the most evenly divided battlegrounds across the country. Democrats haven‚Äôt won a Senate race in the Tar Heel State since 2008, but the party believes its candidate, former Governor Roy Cooper, may be poised to change that next year. Republicans have coalesced around Michael Whatley, the former Republican National Committee chair who has received support from Trump. Early polling gives Cooper an advantage. A Harper Polling survey showed Cooper up 8 points over Whatley (47 percent to 39 percent). It surveyed 600 likely voters from November 9-10, 2025, and had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. Meanwhile, a Change Research survey from September showed Cooper with a 7-point lead (48 percent to 41 percent). It surveyed 855 likely voters from September 2-8, 2025, and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.6 percentage points. Ohio Ohio, once a premier battleground state, has steadily become more Republican over the past decade, backing Trump in each of his presidential races. But Democrats view the race to finish out Vice President JD Vance‚Äôs full term as potentially being competitive. Senator Jon Husted, appointed to the seat after Trump and Vance‚Äôs victory last November, is viewed as the likely Republican nominee. Former Senator Sherrod Brown, who lost reelection last November, is seen as the frontrunner on the Democratic side. Ohio backed Trump by about 11 points last November. The most recent polls point to a close race. An Emerson College poll of 850 registered voters from December 6-8, 2025, showed Husted up three points (49 percent to 46 percent), but a Bowling Green State University survey of 800 registered voters from October 2-14, 2025, had Brown up by a single point (49 percent to 48 percent). Texas Democrats have been eyeing Texas as an emerging swing state for years‚Äîbut that dream hasn‚Äôt come to fruition. They are hoping the 2026 midterms could be another opportunity to make inroads with the largest red state in the nation. How competitive the race could become may depend on the primary. On the Republican side, Senator John Cornyn is facing a challenge from Attorney General Ken Paxton and Representative Wesley Hunt. Cornyn is viewed as a stronger incumbent, and polls suggest he would be in a stronger position than his rivals. The Democratic primary pits Representative Jasmine Crockett against state legislator James Talarico. So far, polling gives Crockett, who has risen to national prominence, an advantage. A University of Houston/Texas Southern University poll from earlier in the fall showed Cornyn with a 6-point lead over Crockett (50 percent to 44 percent) and a three-point lead over Talarico (48 percent to 45 percent). Paxton led Crockett by 2 points (49 percent to 47 percent) and Talarico by 3 points (49 percent to 46 percent). Meanwhile, Hunt led Crockett by five points (50 percent to 45 percent) and Talarico by 6 points (50 percent to 44 percent). The poll surveyed 1,650 registered voters from September 19 to October 1, 2025. Iowa Democrats are also hoping to make the Iowa Senate competitive, vacated by GOP Senator Joni Ernst. Like Ohio, it has shifted away from Democrats during the Trump era, backing him by 13 points last November. Republican candidates include Representative Ashley Hinson and former state Senator Jim Carlin; Hinson has been endorsed by Trump. Democratic candidates include state Senator Zach Wahls, state Representative Josh Turek and KNIA market director Nathan Sage. There have been no polls on the race since Ernst said she wasn‚Äôt running. What People Are Saying NRSC Regional Press Secretary Nick Puglia told Newsweek: ‚ÄúDemocrats are the most unpopular they‚Äôve ever been with the American people. Radical leftists like Jon Ossoff, Janet Mills and Roy Cooper think the answer is more progressive policies like men in women‚Äôs sports and higher taxes. Good luck with that.‚Äù Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee spokesperson Maeve Coyle wrote in an October statement: ‚ÄúThis week, as open enrollment begins, millions of Americans across the country are receiving notices that their health care premiums have skyrocketed ‚Äì in many cases doubling or more ‚Äì because Senate Republicans continue refusing to address the health care crisis that they created. These health care price hikes will hurt working families and will be an electoral albatross for every Republican Senator and candidate who created this crisis, and voters will hold them accountable in 2026.‚Äù What Happens Next Candidates will spend the coming months making their cases to voters in hopes of winning a majority of support in key races. Issues like Trump‚Äôs approval rating and the economy are likely to loom over the midterms.
news.summary: Democrats are hoping to win back control of the Senate in 2026 despite a challenging map.
news.author: Andrew Stanton

news.title: 'Where‚Äôs Joe?' Why Biden's Christmas Family Photo Has Gone Viral For All The Wrong Reasons
news.text:
A picture is worth a thousand words, and former United States President Joe Biden must have been reminded of the timeless phrase after his Christmas Eve family photo blew up on social media‚Äînot for all the right reasons.
In the photograph shared on X, Biden stands at the back of the group, partly obscured by his wife Jill Biden, while other family members, including his son Hunter Biden, occupy more prominent positions in the frame. The former president‚Äôs daughter Ashley, Hunter‚Äôs wife Melissa Cohen and two other grandchildren are also seen in the family photo.

Wishing you a peaceful and joyful Christmas Eve filled with love. pic.twitter.com/OB5GouvxTJ
‚Äî Joe Biden (@JoeBiden) December 25, 2025

Despite Biden‚Äôs caption wishing followers a ‚Äúpeaceful and joyful Christmas Eve‚Äù, many users quickly zeroed in on the former president‚Äôs placement, leading to a flurry of reactions online. Users on X and other platforms joked that Biden was ‚Äúhidden‚Äù or ‚Äúburied‚Äù in his own family photo, questioning why he appeared almost invisible behind family. Some even suggested the image looked like a deliberate snub or a symbolic sign of diminished stature.
‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs disrespectful to put the eldest family member in the back of a photo taken for the former president‚Äôs social media,‚Äù a user wrote.
Some questioned Hunter‚Äôs placement in the picture, with a user saying: ‚ÄúHunter is the alpha now.‚Äù
‚ÄúOuch,‚Äù an X user commented. ‚ÄúWay to shove the family namesake to the back, cover part of his face, then post it to his social media account.‚Äù
Several commenters also pointed to Biden‚Äôs recent health challenges, including treatment for prostate cancer, as context for their reactions, though others defended the family and offered warm holiday wishes.
‚ÄúWishing you a peaceful Christmas Eve too, Mr President. Let‚Äôs hope the spirit of goodwill extends into the new year and helps bridge some of the divides we‚Äôve seen. The image is a nice reminder of simpler times,‚Äù a user wrote.
Since stepping away from the 2024 presidential race, Joe Biden has largely receded from the public and political spotlight.
During his time in office, however, Biden frequently drew attention for a series of high-profile verbal slips and faltering debate performances. These included mistakenly referring to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy as ‚ÄúPresident Putin,‚Äù confusing then Vice President Kamala Harris with Donald Trump, and misnaming Defence Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III during a public address.
Earlier this month, Biden again stumbled over his words while delivering a speech, failing to clearly say the name of the country he once led. While criticising what he described as ‚Äúthe many crises caused by this administration,‚Äù he misspoke, saying, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre the United States of Amerigotit‚Ä¶ That‚Äôs who we are. We‚Äôre the US.‚Äù
In May, Biden‚Äôs post-presidential office disclosed that he had been diagnosed with prostate cancer that had spread to his bones. He completed radiation treatment for the aggressive illness in late October and has since been seen spending time with his family, including during Thanksgiving celebrations.
news.summary: Despite Biden‚Äôs caption wishing followers a ‚Äúpeaceful & joyful Christmas Eve‚Äù, many users quickly zeroed in on the ex-president‚Äôs placement, leading to a flurry of reactions online
news.author: Apoorva Misra,News18

news.title: Democratic Strategist Julian Epstein Shares Whether Party Can Still Count On Left-Wing Billionaire Donors
news.text:
Democratic strategist Julian Epstein said Friday that his party can no longer assume it will enjoy automatic backing from wealthy liberal donors.

The Democratic National Committee‚Äôs principal fundraising committee reported roughly $12 million in cash on hand while carrying nearly $16 million in outstanding debt from a recent loan, according to filings with the Federal Election Commission. During a discussion on ‚ÄúKudlow,‚Äù guest host David Asman asked why prominent left-wing billionaires have not stepped in to help stabilize the DNC‚Äôs finances. Epstein said the silence from the donor class reflects a broader ‚Äúvote of no confidence‚Äù in the Democratic Party.

‚ÄúI think what we‚Äôre seeing with the donor class right now is a lack of confidence, a vote of no confidence in the Democrats. And I think it stems back to a couple things,‚Äù Epstein told Asman. ‚ÄúThe lie about Biden‚Äôs mental health, the incompetency of the Harris campaign, and the fact that all of the data shows that the Democratic Party is deeply out of touch on almost every single economic and social cultural issue.‚Äù

Epstein said elite donors helped pull Democrats away from the political center. (RELATED: Democrats Ask For Money While Blaming Trump, GOP For Shutdown)

‚ÄúThe irony here, David, is that the donor class is perhaps the most leftist class of the Democratic Party. They are the ones driving the Democratic Party to be out of touch. Now they are withholding their money because they don‚Äôt like the results of sort of the far-left drift,‚Äù Epstein added. ‚ÄúSo I don‚Äôt really know where the Democrats go from here. I‚Äôve argued for a Sister Souljah moment, but I don‚Äôt think a lot of people are listening to that.‚Äù

The DNC‚Äôs debt problems are not new, as the committee entered the midterm cycle months ago at a clear financial disadvantage, weighed down by lingering debt from former Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äôs 2024 presidential campaign and weak donor enthusiasm. At the time, the Republican National Committee reported raising $10.7 million in September with roughly $86 million in cash on hand, while the DNC brought in $10.3 million and held about $12 million in reserves.

The strain partly traces back to liabilities carried over from Harris‚Äôs failed presidential bid, which spent roughly $1.5 billion in just over three months. The DNC shelled out another $1.6 million in September to settle campaign-related bills, pushing total payments linked to Harris‚Äôs effort past $20 million, according to Axios.

All republished articles must include our logo, our reporter‚Äôs byline and their DCNF affiliation. For any questions about our guidelines or partnering with us, please contact licensing@dailycallernewsfoundation.org.
news.summary: 'Democratic Party is deeply out of touch'
news.author: Mariane Angela

news.title: Kamala Harris Offers Young Women Dating Advice: ‚ÄòFriday Night or Sunday Morning Relationship‚Äô
news.text:
In a recent podcast appearance, former Vice President and failed presidential candidate Kamala Harris shared her dating advice for single women.

Harris began by advising listeners to ‚Äúbe kind to yourself and choose to be with someone who is kind.‚Äù She claimed a good partner is someone who allows you to laugh at yourself and with them. She added that people should choose someone they enjoy spending time with in both everyday activities, like going to the grocery store or taking a walk, and in more formal settings.

The core of her commentary came when she described the concept of different types of relationships depending on a person‚Äôs current phase in life. Laughing alongside the host, she said, ‚ÄúDepending on what phase you‚Äôre in, maybe you‚Äôre going to choose that you want to have that kind of Friday night relationship or you want that Sunday morning relationship.‚Äù Harris acknowledged that sometimes the two align‚Äîand sometimes they do not. She added, ‚ÄúSometimes you can get both, and sometimes it‚Äôs oil and water.‚Äù

Continuing, Harris urged people to be honest about the kind of relationship they‚Äôre in and not try to force it into something else, stating, ‚ÄúThe first step is to be honest about what you‚Äôre in. And not try and make it something that it‚Äôs not because that usually doesn‚Äôt work out so well.‚Äù She added, ‚ÄúBe in those phases where you are having fun. Be in those phases where you have a sense of ‚ÄòI just want something more.‚Äô‚Äù

Harris made the remarks during an appearance on the Rich Little Brokegirls podcast, where she was promoting her new memoir, 107 Days. The interview was part of a broader book tour, which she has focused on instead of addressing questions about a potential 2028 presidential campaign.
news.summary:
In a recent podcast appearance, former Vice President and failed presidential candidate Kamala Harris shared her dating advice for single women.


The post Kamala Harris Offers Young Women Dating Advice: ‚ÄòFriday Night or Sunday Morning Relationship‚Äô appeared first on Breitbart.
news.author: Jasmyn Jordan

news.title: Trump tells The Post he‚Äôs not ready to embrace Somaliland independence ‚Äî unlike pal Netanyahu
news.text:
WASHINGTON ‚Äî President Trump told The Post that he won‚Äôt quickly follow Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in recognizing the independence of Somaliland ‚Äî saying he has to ‚Äústudy‚Äù his longtime Mideast ally‚Äôs pitch on behalf of the breakaway republic.

Israel on Friday became the world‚Äôs first country to recognize Somaliland‚Äôs split from anarchic Somalia and Netanyahu vowed to deliver a message to Trump, with whom he is meeting Monday.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll communicate to President Trump your willingness and desire to join the Abraham Accords,‚Äù Netanyahu told Somaliland President Abdirahman Mohamed Abdullahi in a video call celebrating the diplomatic breakthrough.

But Trump said that he wasn‚Äôt swayed and expects his talks with Netanyahu will prioritize the Gaza Strip, where Trump brokered an October cease-fire and now chairs a United Nations-approved Board of Peace to oversee implementation and reconstruction.

‚ÄúJust say, ‚ÄòNo, comma, not at this ‚Äî,'‚Äù Trump told The Post in a phone interview, before modifying his answer on recognizing Somaliland to: ‚ÄúJust say, ‚ÄòNo.'‚Äù

‚ÄúDoes anyone know what Somaliland is, really?‚Äù Trump asked aloud from his golf course in West Palm Beach.

Trump sounded unimpressed by the Muslim-majority state offering to join the Abraham Accords ‚Äî through which Bahrain, Morocco, Sudan and the UAE established relations with Israel ‚Äî and equally unimpressed by Somaliland‚Äôs offer of land for a US naval base near the mouth of the Red Sea.

Asked about Somaliland‚Äôs offer to the US of a military port, Trump dismissively replied, ‚ÄúBig deal.‚Äù

‚ÄúEverything is under study,‚Äù the president added.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll study it. I study a lot of things and always make great decisions and they turn out to be correct.‚Äù

Gen. Dagvin Anderson, the chief of U.S. Africa Command, visited Somaliland last month, buoying local hopes for a deal with the US, as some of Trump‚Äôs key MAGA loyalists rally behind the little-known region.

One of Trump‚Äôs most ardent allies in Congress, Rep. Scott Perry (R-Pa.) is the sponsor of the ‚ÄúRepublic of Somaliland Independence Act,‚Äù with cosponsors including Reps. Tom Tiffany (R-Wis.), Andy Ogles (R-Tenn.) and Tim Burchett (R-Tenn.).

Trump has spent recent weeks railing against Somalia and its citizens ripping off US taxpayers in Minnesota, where state government officials have pinned the blame on Democratic Gov. Tim Walz, then-Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äô running mate in last year‚Äôs election.

Somaliland, a former British protectorate, has been de facto independent of the formerly Italian-ruled bulk of Somalia since 1991 and has built a relatively stable democracy with peaceful transitions of power ‚Äî unlike the Mogadishu-based central government, which has been beset by civil war.

Mogadishu is the birthplace of Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minn.), who opposes autonomy for the northern region, declaring, ‚Äù As long as I‚Äôm in Congress, no one will take over the seas belonging to the nation of Somalia.‚Äù

The breakaway nation has strong relations with neighboring Ethiopia, but other countries such as Turkey advocate against its independence. 

Trump said in August that he was considering granting Somaliland recognition, saying at the time: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre looking into that right now. Good question, actually. And another complex one, as you know. But we‚Äôre working on that right now ‚Äî Somaliland.‚Äù
news.summary: Israel on Friday became the world's first country to recognize Somaliland's split from anarchic Somalia, with Netanyahu planning to deliver a message to Trump at their Monday Mar-a-Lago meeting.
news.author: Steven Nelson

news.title: Republicans support legalizing weed even as Trump's base frets of brain drain
news.text:
Read More: Gavin Newsom's struggle with black voters jeopardizes White House dreams as he braces for clash with Kamala Harris

By VICTORIA CHURCHILL, US POLITICAL REPORTER

Published: 18:35 GMT, 26 December 2025 | Updated: 19:08 GMT, 26 December 2025

Nearly half of Republican leaders in the US Senate are out of touch with the slight majority of Republican voters when it comes to the issue of marijuana.

A majority of Americans ‚Äì and every group in society ‚Äì back legalization of marijuana, per a JL Partners poll conducted exclusively for the Daily Mail earlier this month.

Some 51 percent of Republicans support legalization, compared to 53 percent of poll respondents overall and 62 percent of Democrats.

JL Partners polled 1,000 registered voters via an online survey on December 20 and 21.

The results also showed that 58 percent of men support legalization, compared with 50 percent of women.

Respondents between the ages of 30 and 49 favored legalization the most, with 61 percent of respondents in that age range supporting the proposal. 

Donald Trump signed an executive order to free up federal restrictions on marijuana on December 18, despite deep reservations from his fiercest allies on Capitol Hill.

North Carolina Republican Senator Budd led 21 of his Senate Republican colleagues in sending a letter to the President urging him to reconsider his decision.

Donald Trump displays an executive order reclassifying marijuana as a less dangerous drug in the Oval Office last Thursday

A majority of Americans ‚Äì and every group in society ‚Äì back legalization of marijuana, per a JL Partners poll conducted exclusively for the Daily Mail earlier this month

Budd was joined on the letter by fellow Republicans including John Barrasso of Wyoming - the Senate majority whip - Tom Cotton of Arkansas, Shelley Moore Capito of West Virginia, James Lankford of Oklahoma, Roger Marshall of Kansas, Pete Ricketts of Nebraska, Tommy Tuberville of Alabama, John Cornyn of Texas, Marsha Blackburn and Bill Hagerty of Tennessee, Jim Banks of Indiana, Ron Johnson of Wisconsin, Mike Crapo of South Dakota, Rick Scott of Florida, Jim Risch of Idaho, Kevin Cramer of North Dakota, Cindy Hyde-Smith of Mississippi, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, Cynthia Lummis of Wyoming, Dave McCormick of Pennsylvania, and Mitch McConnell of Kentucky.

In the letter, senators note that 'evidence shows that marijuana is harmful to its users.'

The letter also warned of damage from marijuana use on 'brain health' and 'permanent IQ loss.'

'[F]acilitating the growth of the marijuana industry is at odds with growing our economy and encouraging healthy lifestyles for Americans,' the letter read.

When signing his executive order, Trump said that he promised to be 'the president of common sense and that is exactly what we are doing.'

He said that 'so many people' reached out to him to endorse the idea, particularly from people suffering from the pain as a result of cancer.

'It doesn't legalize marijuana in any way, shape or form,' he said. 'And in no way sanctions it's use for a recreational drug,' Trump said.

The President pointedly repeated his opposition to the use of illegal drugs as well.

'I always told my kids don't take drugs,' Trump said, telling America's youth to 'just don't do it.'

Trump's executive order reclassifies marijuana from a Schedule I drug with 'no currently accepted medical use' to a Schedule III drug, primarily to allow it to be researched.

Marijuana business stocks spiked on Wall Street as news of the President's decision on the issue was made public.

RepublicansCapitol HillDonald Trump

Share or comment on this article:
Republicans support legalizing weed even as Trump's base frets of brain drain

Add comment
news.summary: Nearly half of Republican leaders in the US Senate are out of touch with the slight majority of Republican voters when it comes to the issue of marijuana.
news.author: Editor,Victoria Churchill

news.title: Did that really happen? Four outrageous stories from Trump‚Äôs first year back that you may have forgotten about
news.text:
In 2019, former White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon told PBS‚Äô Frontline program how President Donald Trump was engaged in a deliberate strategy to overwhelm the press and his critics by rolling out massive and controversial policy changes while distracting them with trolling to keep them from ever focusing on any one thing that could matter.

He described the tactic as ‚Äúflooding the zone.‚Äù

‚ÄúEvery day, we hit them with three things. They'll bite on one, and we'll get all of our stuff done, bang, bang, bang,‚Äù he said. 

Nearly a year into Trump‚Äôs second term, their ‚Äúflood the zone strategy‚Äù has been in full effect. 

His administration has unveiled sweeping changes to how America‚Äôs government operates in ways that have had and will have dramatic effects on how everyday people live for years to come. But those changes have come in such rapid-fire succession that nearly 365 days after Trump was sworn in on a freezing January day last year, it‚Äôs hard to even begin to remember what he‚Äôs done.

Here are some of the wildest stories from the White House in 2025: 

Five days after his swearing-in, Trump committed a Friday-night massacre of the independent inspectors general who root out waste, fraud and abuse within federal agencies and departments.

The late-night purge removed the inspectors general at nearly every Cabinet-level agency without warning and in violation of a longstanding law requiring the president to notify Congress of his intent to fire any such official 30 days before actually doing so.

Only the watchdogs at the Department of Justice and the Department of Homeland Security were permitted to remain in their jobs. 

Trump, who fired a number of inspectors general during his first term in an effort to kneecap their ability to investigate wrongdoing by his appointees, defended the illegal move as ‚Äúvery common‚Äù while speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One en route to the first weekend golf outing of his second term.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know them ‚Ä¶ but some people thought that some were unfair or some were not doing their job. It‚Äôs a very standard thing to do,‚Äù he said.

The purge took out Senate-confirmed watchdogs at the departments of Defense, State, Transportation, Labor, Health and Human Services, Veterans Affairs, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Energy, Commerce, Treasury and Agriculture, as well as the Environmental Protection Agency, Small Business Administration and the Social Security Administration. The move allowed Trump fill the positions with loyalists. 

Less than a month in the White House, Trump hosted Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for an official visit. 

Netanyahu‚Äôs trip was his first appearance there in quite some time, as Trump‚Äôs predecessor, former president Joe Biden, had declined to invite the Israeli leader due to election-year sensitivities around Israel‚Äôs brutal campaign of bombing civilian targets in Gaza to retaliate for the October 7, 2023, terror attacks by Hamas.

Just weeks earlier, the Biden and Trump teams had shared credit for what was billed at the time as a ceasefire and hostage exchange deal between Israel and Hamas, though the agreement quickly collapsed.

But as Netanyahu stood beside him in the East Room, Trump offered up another plan for the war-torn territory that sent Middle East experts‚Äô heads spinning as the president claimed the U.S. would ‚Äútake over‚Äù Gaza, displacing the 2.1 million Palestinians living there while the territory is rebuilt as ‚Äúthe Riviera of the Middle East.‚Äù 

The president‚Äôs shocking proposal to put the Gaza Strip ‚Äî territory that Israel has occupied since the end of the 1967 Six-Day War ‚Äî under American control came at the start of a madcap marathon press conference in the East Room following a bilateral meeting with Netanyahu, the first foreign leader Trump has hosted since returning to the White House last month. 

He claimed that ‚Äúeverybody‚Äù he had spoken to about the plan ‚Äúloves the idea of the United States owning that piece of land, developing and creating thousands of jobs with something that will be magnificent.‚Äù

‚ÄúI've studied this very closely over a lot of months, and I've seen it from every different angle, and it's a very, very dangerous place to be, and it's only going to get worse. And I think this is an idea that's gotten tremendous ... praise. And if the United States can help to bring stability and peace in the Middle East, we'll do that,‚Äù Trump added. 

His comments drew widespread criticism around the world, with Saudi Arabia saying it ‚Äúunequivocally rejected‚Äù the forced displacement of Palestinians in Gaza, and Hamas branding the idea ‚Äúridiculous and absurd.‚Äù

The White House walked back the idea less than a day later, and the president‚Äôs aborted plan was later superseded by the ceasefire agreement negotiated between Israel and Hamas with the aid of Egypt, Qatar and other regional powers in October. 

During his 2024 campaign against former Biden, and later former vice president Kamala Harris, Trump was fond of telling supporters that he would be their ‚Äúretribution‚Äù if he was elected again.

Since taking office, he‚Äôs made good on that promise in ways that critics say have strained the rule of law and undermined the independence of the Department of Justice. 

But Trump took an unprecedented step on his ‚Äúretribution‚Äù tour in April by ordering the Department of Justice to investigate one of his most prominent first-term critics ‚Äî for anything that can be found to investigate. 

The order singled out Miles Taylor, a veteran of multiple Republican administrations who served as chief of staff to then-Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly during the president‚Äôs first term. During that time, Taylor infamously penned an anonymous New York Times op-ed ‚Äî and later a book ‚Äî describing efforts by Trump administration personnel to shield the government from Trump‚Äôs worst instincts.

White House Staff Secretary Will Scharf said at the time that the order stripped Taylor ‚Äúof any active clearance that he has in light of his past activities involving classified information‚Äù even though Taylor‚Äôs writings weren‚Äôt alleged to have included anything classified at all.

‚ÄúIt's also going to order the Department of Justice to investigate his activities, to see what else might come up in that context, given his egregious behavior during your previous administration,‚Äù Scharf added.

The same day, Trump signed a similar order directing a probe of Chris Krebs, the security expert who headed the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency during his first term. Krebs had incurred Trump‚Äôs ire in the immediate wake of the 2020 election ‚Äî which Trump lost to Joe Biden ‚Äî by stating publicly that the election was the most secure in the country‚Äôs 250-year history. 

He also said there was ‚Äúno evidence that any voting system deleted or lost votes, changed votes, or was in any way compromised‚Äù during the 2020 election, directly contradicting Trump‚Äôs false claims of fraud. 

That order further targeted Krebs‚Äô employer, the cybersecurity firm SentinelOne, by ordering the stripping of security clearances ‚Äúheld by individuals at entities associated with Krebs, including SentinelOne, pending a review of whether such clearances are consistent with the national interest.‚Äù 

Eight months later, neither Taylor nor Krebs has been accused of any crime, but Trump has continued to escalate his campaign of revenge against critics and adversaries by ordering the Justice Department to prosecute ex-FBI director James Comey and New York State Attorney General Letitia James, among others.

Those efforts have thus far been stymied by federal judges who dismissed a pair of indictments against both Comey and James on the grounds that the ex-White House official who Trump installed as a prosecutor in Virginia, Lindsey Halligan, had been unlawfully appointed. 

Less than a month after he swore to ‚Äúpreserve, protect and defend‚Äù the U.S. Constitution, Trump took to social media to push back against the myriad challenges to his blitzkrieg of executive actions and threats to federal agencies from the then-Elon Musk-ed Department of Government Efficiency by invoking a movie quote from a film about Napoleon, who justified his despotic regime as the will of the people of France.

Writing on X and Truth Social on February 15, Trump said: ‚ÄúHe who saves his Country does not violate any Law.‚Äù

Trump, whose efforts to gut federal funding, fire thousands of aid workers and unilaterally redefine the 14th Amendment had been swiftly blocked by federal courts across the country in the opening salvos of what has become a series of months-long legal battles, appeared to be lifting a line 1970 film Waterloo, in which actor Rod Steiger‚Äôs Napoleon states that he ‚Äúdid not ‚Äòusurp‚Äô the crown.‚Äù

‚ÄúI found it in the gutter, and I picked it up with my sword, and it was the people ‚Ä¶ who put it on my head,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúHe who saves a nation violates no law,‚Äù Steiger said.

Four days later, Trump went even further by crowning himself ‚Äúking‚Äù of his former home, New York City, after the Department of Transportation purported to order the withholding of federal funds to New York unless it nixed the congestion pricing plan that the Democratic-led city government implemented.

‚ÄúCONGESTION PRICING IS DEAD,‚Äù he wrote February 19 on Truth Social. ‚ÄúManhattan, and all of New York, is SAVED. LONG LIVE THE KING!‚Äù

The White House‚Äôs X account then shared his statement with a mock cover of Time magazine featuring a portrait of the president wearing a crown with the caption ‚Äúlong live the king.‚Äù

Then-White House Deputy Chief of Staff Taylor Budowich also shared an AI-generated image of the president wearing a crown and regal cape.

In response, ‚Äã‚ÄãNew York‚Äôs Metropolitan Transportation Authority sued Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy and federal transportation officials, arguing the Trump administration unlawfully and ‚Äúprecipitously ‚Äî and for blatantly political reasons‚Äî purported to ‚Äòterminate‚Äô the program, as then-candidate Trump proclaimed he would do in his first week in office.‚Äù

A federal judge later blocked the Trump administration from withholding funds in retaliation for the congestion pricing scheme, and the MTA‚Äôs lawsuit seeking to permanently enjoin the administration from doing so remains ongoing.
news.summary: A selection of the craziest stories from Trump‚Äôs first year back in office
news.author: Andrew Feinberg

news.title: Bari Weiss defends decision to pull 60 Minutes episode on El Salvador prison
news.text:
CBS News‚Äô editor-in-chief, Bari Weiss, defended her decision to pull a 60 Minutes episode on allegations investigating a notorious prison in El Salvador, arguing that the network‚Äôs priority was to ensure its coverage was ‚Äúcomprehensive and fair‚Äù.

In the memo sent to staff on Christmas Eve, Weiss said news organizations needed to do more to win back the trust of the American public and vowed that ‚Äúno amount of outrage‚Äù would ‚Äúderail us‚Äù.

‚ÄúWe are not out to score points with one side of the political spectrum or to win followers on social media,‚Äù according to the memo, signed by Weiss and other CBS News leadership and published in full by several media outlets. ‚ÄúWe are out to inform the American public and to get the story right.‚Äù

The internal battle over the story exploded into public view after CBS announced the segment would not be a part of the show, despite extensive promotion. Weiss‚Äôs last-minute decision to hold the episode sparked outrage and charges of censorship amid Donald Trump‚Äôs second administration, though some conservative commentators generally aligned with the president have defended the move. In a private email sent to 60 Minutes correspondents that was subsequently made public, CBS correspondent Sharyn Alfonsi, who spent weeks reporting the episode, called the decision a ‚Äúpolitical one‚Äù.

In the memo to staff, Weiss acknowledged the uproar her decision had caused internally and externally ‚Äì but she rejected the accusation that politics played a role in her determination to hold the segment.

‚ÄúSuch editorial decisions can cause a firestorm, particularly on a slow news week,‚Äù Weiss wrote. ‚ÄúAnd the standards for fairness we are holding ourselves to, particularly on contentious subjects, will surely feel controversial to those used to doing things one way. But to fulfill our mission, it‚Äôs necessary.‚Äù

Weiss has said she was concerned about the episode airing without a sufficient response from the Trump administration. But Alfonsi said it had been ‚Äúscreened five times‚Äù as well as cleared by CBS attorneys along with its standards and practices department. She also said her team had unsuccessfully requested comment from the White House, the US state department, and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS).

‚ÄúIf the administration‚Äôs refusal to participate becomes a valid reason to spike a story, we have effectively handed them a ‚Äòkill switch‚Äô for any reporting they find inconvenient,‚Äù Alfonsi wrote.

The episode has since appeared online, after it was published by a streaming platform owned by Global TV, the network that has the rights to 60 Minutes in Canada. In it, Alfonsi visits the prison in El Salvador and interviews deportees who offered powerful testimony about torture and abuse inside the notorious prison where the Trump administration had sent more than 200 Venezuelan migrants from the US in what a federal judge recently ruled was a violation of their due process rights.

CBS‚Äôs decision to hold the episode comes amid a widening feud between the Trump administration and 60 Minutes ‚Äì one of journalism‚Äôs most venerated institutions known for hard-hitting investigations. During the 2024 election, Trump declined to sit for an interview with 60 Minutes, then sued the network over how the show handled an interview with his Democratic opponent, Kamala Harris. In a highly controversial move, Paramount, the parent company of CBS, agreed to pay Trump $16m to settle the lawsuit.

Earlier in December, Trump fumed on Truth Social that the network had treated him ‚Äúfar worse since the so-called ‚Äòtakeover,‚Äô than they have ever treated me before‚Äù.

‚ÄúIf they are friends, I‚Äôd hate to see my enemies!‚Äù the Republican added. A week earlier, he assailed the show for an interview with his ally turned critic, the outgoing Republican congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene, whom he called a ‚Äúvery poorly prepared Traitor‚Äù, and said of parent company Paramount: ‚ÄúTHEY ARE NO BETTER THAN THE OLD OWNERSHIP.‚Äù

Weiss‚Äôs management of CBS has come under sharp scrutiny since she was installed as CBS News‚Äôs editor-in-chief by Paramount‚Äôs CEO, David Ellison, the son of Larry Ellison, a Trump ally and donor who is one of the world‚Äôs richest people. Paramount also acquired Weiss‚Äôs Free Press, the conservative-friendly publication she founded after leaving the New York Times as a columnist, in a reported $150m deal.

Her appointment was met with frustration and concern by CBS‚Äôs editorial staff while media watchdogs questioned Weiss‚Äôs qualifications to lead the storied news network and raised concerns about further media politicization. Weiss, who built a reputation as a provocative opinion writer and media operator, has no experience working in broadcast television.

Paramount is now waging an extraordinary hostile takeover bid to gain control of Warner Bros Discovery, which had reached a deal to sell its storied film and television properties to Netflix. Trump has made clear that he plans to be involved in the acquisition‚Äôs regulatory review process.
news.summary:
CBS News editor-in-chief argues in memo that network‚Äôs priority was ‚Äòcomprehensive and fair‚Äô coverage


Who is Bari Weiss, the new editor-in-chief of CBS News?

CBS News‚Äô editor-in-chief, Bari Weiss, defended her decision to pull a 60 Minutes episode on allegations investigating a notorious prison in El Salvador, arguing that the network‚Äôs priority was to ensure its coverage was ‚Äúcomprehensive and fair‚Äù.

In the memo sent to staff on Christmas Eve, Weiss said news organizations needed to do more to win back the trust of the American public and vowed that ‚Äúno amount of outrage‚Äù would ‚Äúderail us‚Äù.

 Continue reading...
news.author: Lauren Gambino

news.title: Democrats and Republicans tied on economy heading into 2026, survey finds
news.text:
For Republicans, the findings serve as a bit of a wake-up call. The party has traditionally held the advantage in voters‚Äô opinions on the handling of the economy, a matter that has remained at the forefront of voters‚Äô minds for the last few election cycles. 

President Donald Trump and former Vice President Kamala Harris made the economy a focal point of their campaigns, with the victorious president promising to lower costs on Day One and revitalize the economy through an ‚ÄúAmerica First‚Äù agenda. 

But polling suggests that voters are not pleased with the results they have seen so far from the GOP trifecta in Washington. In August, a Third Way survey found that Republicans held a substantial lead over Democrats in handling the economy, with 42% to 36% support. They held a slight lead over inflation and trailed Democrats by only two percentage points in handling the cost of living.

The August poll came out after congressional Republicans successfully passed the One Big Beautiful Bill Act and signed it into law, legislation that the GOP has hailed as the largest tax cut for Americans despite opposition over the drastic cuts to Medicaid. 

The think tank found that nothing that occurred in the first six months of Trump‚Äôs second term on Capitol Hill and in the White House did much to alleviate voters‚Äô concerns about the state of the country. However, many had eyes on how voters‚Äô temperaments improved in the days and months following Trump‚Äôs signing the Big Beautiful Bill Act into law on July 4. 

Six months later, voters are trending toward Democrats on the economy after they were underwater in the think tank‚Äôs summer survey, and they hold an 11-point lead on the cost of living compared to the survey released in August. Much of that has come after Trump‚Äôs tariffs have affected key voting blocs, such as farmers and small business owners.

But that does not mean Democrats can take a large victory lap. The centrist think tank found that, while Democrats are holding slight leads on key economic matters, they are unable to match what is needed to have a resounding victory in 2026.

‚ÄúPresident Trump and congressional Republicans have ceded the advantage on these issues they held just one year ago,‚Äù Third Way wrote in its analysis. ‚ÄúThe question is whether congressional Democrats can fully convince Americans that they will be focused on cost-of-living and not that scandal of the week.‚Äù

Several Democrats have largely attributed their 2024 losses, including Trump‚Äôs defeat of Harris, to the party‚Äôs failure to address kitchen-table matters and instead focusing on social and cultural matters. A handful of lawmakers came out in the aftermath of last year‚Äôs election to blame their party‚Äôs messaging on the economy and criticize the emphasis put on matters such as abortion or the LGBTQ community. 

Affordability has proven to be a winning message for Democrats this year. In November, Democrats dominated the three top elections of the 2025 cycle, with victories in the New Jersey and Virginia gubernatorial races and a historic win for Zohran Mamdani in New York City‚Äôs mayoral contest. 

Despite Gov.-elect Abigail Spanberger (D-VA) and Gov.-elect Mikie Sherrill (D-NJ) favoring centrist agendas, and Mamdani turning heads with his democratic-socialist policies, all three candidates hammered hard on the economy and affordability to flip key areas and significantly outperform the GOP.

‚ÄúDemocrats really never dominated on trust on the economy, what we‚Äôve been able to do is fight it to a draw in periods that have been very good for us electorally,‚Äù Matt Bennett, Third Way‚Äôs EVP of public affairs, told Politico Playbook. ‚ÄúWhat we need to do is at least keep it close, and I think that‚Äôs where we are.‚Äù
news.summary: Voter confidence in Democrats and Republicans regarding the handling of the economy is evenly split, according to recent polling, highlighting the challenge both parties face on a central matter ahead of the 2026 midterm elections. A survey released on Thursday from Third Way, a centrist-left think tank, found that both parties are tied at 38% […]
news.author: Rachel Schilke

news.title: Kamala '28 Makes Even A CNN Democrat Laugh!
news.text:
CNN News Central

JOHN BERMAN: One curveball here, Meghan. I'm a little bit obsessed with Florida Governor Ron DeSantis and his Twitter feed over the last six months. Because, look, he ran for president and did not do well, right? And I think a lot of people saw him as stiff, unapproachable, prickly. 

So on social media the last several months, he's tweeting about music. He's tweeting about sports. He's offering sort of unplugged commentary. I don't know if you've had a chance to see it, But it's the kind of stuff that makes you think either this guy has no Fs left to give, or, he thinks I need to show a different side of myself if I'm going to have a future in politics. 

. . . Melik, who do you think Republicans fear the most? 

MELIK ABDUL: I think that Republicans, well, who they should fear the most, I would argue it's between Shapiro and Gavin Newsom. 

You remember the Fox News debate between Gavin Newsom or Ron DeSantis? Gavin Newsom actually performed very well. And even though he's from California, he is very, he looks the part. He's very stately. And those types of things matter from an optics perspective. But also, Shapiro being from a battleground state. I think that that is something that we also have to watch. I don't think that Wes Moore, he's the governor of Maryland. No one cares about the governor of Maryland. I don't think Pritzker, he has a lot of money. It won't matter. 

I think that the two standouts will be Gavin Newsom, and Shapiro.

And notably, who we're not talking about, Kamala Harris. 

BERMAN: Why aren't we talking about her, Meghan? [Abdul chuckles.]

MEGHAN HAYS: [Nervous laughter] Uh, [Abdul laughs out loud] you know, it's interesting [more nervous laughter.] 

I just am not sure [Abdul having a ball, continues to chuckle] she, I don't know that she's going to run. I know she talks about leaving the door open, but I think running, you have to have a base. You have to be able to raise a lot of money, and I think there's a lot of people in the race, and I'm not sure that that's a path she wants to take again.

But, you know, again, there's probably going to be 20, 25 candidates. So, the water is warm.
news.summary:
For politicians, scandal and controversy can be bad. But becoming the object of ridicule can be even more devastating. So if Kamala Harris happens to read these words, we'd advise her NOT to watch CNN's 7 am Christmas Day hour. What she'd find under the tree would be something worse than a lump of coal. It'd be a steaming pile of . . . ridicule.¬†

It's almost 2026, so why not a horse race segment on 2028 presidential contenders? After former Biden aide Meghan Hays and Republican strategist Melik Abdul named their favorites, Abdul observed:¬†


"Notably, who we're not talking about: Kamala Harris."


Host John Berman put it to Hays: "Why aren't we talking about her, Meghan?"¬†

Abdul was manifestly amused to see Hays thusly put on the spot, and even Berman couldn't suppress a grin. Hays proceeded to engage in an extended bout of nervous laughter. She questioned whether Harris would run, and was dubious about the existence of a Harris base or her ability to raise money.

On second thought, perhaps Kamala should¬†v
news.author: Mark Finkelstein

The engagement party, which took place last December, will see Holly and Adam with his family during happier times, before their toxic fallout occurred and he disinvited all but one of his relatives from the wedding.

 Holly Ramsay gushes it's her 'last Christmas as a Miss' just days before her wedding to Adam Peaty 
But according to The Sun, the cracks were already starting to show at the time, with Caroline having several grievances at the party.
A source told the publication: 'Adam's family were at the engagement party, when relations were much better. Things went downhill from there.
'His mum was unhappy some of the family weren't there and confronted Gordon at the event.
'Guests were made to sign non-disclosure agreements and hand in phones as the party was filmed.'
It was also revealed that Peaty's sister Bethany is the only member of his side who appears to have survived the bitter family fallout ahead of his wedding.
The hen-do snub sparked a huge response from the Peaty family, with Adam's aunt Louise blasting her nephew and his fianc√©e, Holly, in a series of Instagram comments.
She later claimed her sister Caroline wasn't invited to their wedding due to her appearance and not having the correct 'look'.
But one member of Peaty's family appears to have survived the feud, his sister Bethany - who did make the cut for Holly's picture-perfect Cotswolds hen do.
It's been reported that the real reason Bethany made the cut is that she 'fits in' to the Ramsays' glamorous world because 'she's blonde and pretty'.
There are claims that Bethany herself has had her head turned by the celebrity lifestyle, and has been asked to be one of Holly's bridesmaids.
A friend close to the family told the publication: 'Bethany has always been very close to Adam and she is really taken with the celebrity lifestyle, she's had her head turned by all the glitz and glamour.
'She was over the moon to be at the hen party, hanging out with Victoria Beckham and couldn't wait to tell all her friends about it. She really fits in with the glam world ‚Äì she's blonde and very pretty.'
Earlier this week it was claimed that Adam and Holly have reportedly sparked outrage after banning the public from a historic church for their wedding day.
According to a new report, the ceremony itself will last just 90 minutes, yet the couple have allegedly block-booked the abbey so no other weddings can take place. 
Tourists are expected to be denied entry, with security stationed around the site to prevent onlookers from taking photos.
While hiring the abbey for a wedding typically costs around ¬£2,500, the pair are thought to be paying several thousand more to secure exclusive use of the venue.
And a picture of a notice posted at the abbey states it is 'closed all day for a wedding' on December 27. 
The decision has not gone down well with locals, with one resident telling the publication: 'It seems rather selfish to be hiring the abbey for the whole day when your wedding service only lasts for an hour and a half or so.'
The Daily Mail has contacted Adam and Holly's representatives for comment. 
The toxic family feud currently overshadowing Holly's imminent wedding to Adam was brushed aside on Monday evening as they dined with friends at her father's Mayfair restaurant.
With guests already arriving ahead of the ceremony, Ramsay dined out on prawns and caviar-coated sushi at Ramsay's Lucky Cat eatery, where a lavish meal from the 'chef's table' costs as much as ¬£180 per person.

Have YOU got a story? Email tips@dailymail.com 
By ASHLEIGH GRAY 
 Published:10:22 EST, 26 December 2025 |Updated:11:20 EST, 26 December 2025 

Brooks Nader turned heads as she enjoyed a night out in Aspen, Colorado on Thursday.
The 28-year-old model ‚Äî who recently revealed why she dissolved her lip filler ‚Äî flaunted her slender figure in a skintight black bodysuit complete with thigh-high black boots.
Her long-sleeved ensemble boasted dramatic shearling cuffs and she added a thick belt that accentuated her trim waistline.

Nader pulled her lengthy, blonde-highlighted locks into a sleek ponytail style with a center part.
She showed off a glossy red manicure while carrying a small black Herm√®s handbag. 
It comes days after the Sports Illustrated cover star was forced to acknowledge her fling with former NFL star Tom Brady, 48.

Nader was asked about her brief relationship with the athlete during an appearance on Watch What Happens Live.
She was a guest alongside Real Housewives of Beverly Hills star Erika Jayne, and host Andy Cohen mentioned that they'd both dated men named Tom.

 Brooks Nader reveals that she got rid of her lip filler as a 'Christmas present' to her parents 
For her part, Jayne is still married to estranged husband Tom Girardi.
'Wait! Which Tom did you date?' the blonde beauty asked Nader.
Frustrated, the Love Thy Nader star moaned, 'Andy!' before he yelled, 'Brady! Brady!'
'Well, one's a newscaster, one's in jail. So everything's fine!' she joked before the trio switched topics.
Earlier this week the cover girl revealed that she removed her lip filler as a 'Christmas present' to her parents.
She shared the update with her nearly two million Instagram followers as she documented the process in a video.

Her sister Sarah Jane also shared a video of the scene on TikTok. 
Nader sat back in a chair as the procedure began, dressed in a fitted black ensemble festive, glittery red mouse ears set atop her head.
She flashed a small smile at the camera and her sibling wrote, 'Rare aesthetic: getting your lip filler dissolved after DisneyLand.'
Following the process, Nader posted a closeup selfie, showing off the slightly bruised results.
The media personality wrote at the end of the snippet: 'Got all my lip filler dissolved, that's my Christmas present to Mom & Dad lol.'
